questions.text: What is the most common sequelae of traumatic shoulder dislocation in young adults?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Recurrent shoulder dislocation

 

SEQUELAE OF TRAUMATIC SHOULDER DISLOCATION

 

  • Recurrent dislocation is most common in shoulder joint, accounting for nearly 50% of all dislocations.
  • Most commonly it is subcoracoid type.
  • Other complications include:
    • Muscle, ligament or tendon rupture
    • Nerve or blood vessel damage around the joint
    • Shoulder instability

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Frozen shoulder. Following dislocation, the shoulder shows some degree of limited motion owing to pain or apprehension for some time, which usually spontaneously recovers. However, some patients experience continuous stiffness after dislocation. This may lead to frozen shoulder if not mobilized early.

 

Option C. Normal shoulder healing and movements. The healing after the shoulder dislocation takes around 12-16 weeks. The movements are started slowly under the rehabilitation process.

 

Option D. Subscapular tendinitis. It is a rare complication of shoulder dislocation.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The most common sequealae of the shoulder dislocation is the recurrence of the shoulder dislocation due to instability of the shoulder joint tissues.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female is brought to OPD with the following deformity. What can be inferred from this? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genu Valgum

 

GENU VALGUM

 

  • It is abnormal approximation of knees with abnormally divergent ankles.
  • It can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleolus, when the knees are touching with the patella facing forwards. It is usually < 8 cm.
  • Valgus alignment of lower extremities is normal in child between 2 and 8 years of age (Known as physiological valgus and is maximum between 2 and 4 years).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genu Varum. In Genu Varum (Bow Legs), knees are abnormally divergent (bow-like) and ankles approximated. Bilateral bow legs can be estimated by measuring the distance between the medial malleoli when heels are touching. It should be < 6 cm to label as Genu Varum. Normally, it is 8 cm. The presence of genu varum after 2 years of age can be considered abnormal, as spontaneous resolution of the varus to neutral tibio-femoral alignment by 2 years of age and to adult valgus alignment after 3 years of age is well documented. The causes are similar to genu valgum except that the defective growth is on the medial side. The causes are physiological genu varum (most commonly), tibia vara (growth retardation at the medial aspect of proximal tibial epiphysis & physis). It is treated surgically by overcorrection of mechanical axis to at least 5 degrees valgus, with lateral translation of distal osteotomy fragment, by 4 years of age. High tibial osteotomy just distal to patellar tendon insertion with fibular osteotomy in proximal third diaphysis is recommended.

 

 

Option C. Wind swept deformity means one knee has a valgus deformity and the other knee has a varus deformity. It is classically used for knee deformity of rickets. It is seen in rickets, hereditary dysplasia (epiphyseal dysplasia) of bone and rheumatoid arthritis.

 

 

Option D. Genu recurvatum means hyperextension at the knee joint. Polio is the commonest cause. It is commonly seen in trauma, rheumatoid arthritis, rickets, charcots. It can also be congenital due to intrauterine positioning, which is self-resolving. It is also a common presentation in congenital dislocation of the knee. In children of less than 3 years of age, its most common cause is Blount’s disease.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given question describes the genu valgum deformity (also called as knock knees). It is the abnormal approximation of the knees with abnormally divergent ankles.

choices.text: It is the main restraint in posterior drawer test
It is an extrasynovial structure
It is the main restraint to internal rotation
It originates from anterolateral aspect of medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about PCL? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. It is the main restraint to internal rotation

 

LIGAMENT INJURIES OF THE KNEE JOINT

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCL is the an extrasynovial structure originating from the anterolateral aspect of the medial femoral condyle in the area of intercondylar notch.
  • It is the main restraint to the posterior translation of the knee i.e., the backward gliding of the tibia over the femur.
  • While evaluating the patient during physical examination, PCL is the main restraint in the posterior drawer test.

questions.text: A young marathon runner is participating in a marathon competition. After running for 100 m, he develops pain at the anteromedial aspect of tibia which was mild to start with, but increased on further running. X-ray was normal. The doctor ordered a bone scan. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shin splint

 

STRESS/FATIGUE FRACTURE

 

  • Stress fracture is due to imbalance between load and resistance of bone.
  • It is of 2 types:
    1. Fatigue fracture: Caused by application of abnormal stress on normal bone.
    2. Insufficiency fracture: Caused by normal activity on weak bone.
  • Sites of Stress Fractures:
    1. Lower Extremity:
      • March fracture is a stress fatigue fracture of second metatarsal neck > 3rd metatarsal neck. The most common site is metatarsal neck followed by tibia (proximal third in children, middle third in athlete and lower third in elderly).
      • Tibia stress fracture = Shin splints
      • Femoral neck (inferomedial compression side in young and superior tension side in older patients).
      • Rarely fibula lower end (runner’s fracture).
    2. Upper Extremity:
      • Olecranon is most common site of upper limb stress fractures.
    3. Pelvis and Spine:
      • Pars interarticularis of 5th lumbar vertebral (causing spondylolysis) is commonest in spine.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Load related pain often bilateral
    • The hallmark physical finding is tenderness with palpation and stress.
  • Investigation:
    • MRI provides excellent sensitivity and superior specificity compared to bone scan in differentiating from infections or tumors.
    • Bone scan is preferable for bilateral cases due to feasibility, also bilateral cases go in favour of stress fracture as compared to Infection or tumor and also can scan the whole body.
  • Treatment: Symptomatic with cast and cessation of activity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Lisfranc fracture. A Lisfranc dislocation is a spectrum of injuries involving the tarsometatarsal joints of the foot. The Lisfranc joint is composed of the articulation between the first, second, and third metatarsals bones, and the cuneiform bones. Injury of the joint can range from complete tarsometatarsal displacement with associated fractures and ligamentous tears to partial sprains with no displacement. Lisfranc injuries are uncommon and are often misdiagnosed. Even when recognized and treated promptly, there is still a high risk for chronic disability and complications. There are two main mechanisms of injury: direct, and indirect. A direct mechanism occurs as a crush injury to the joint from motor vehicle collision or industrial accident. An indirect injury is more common and is often associated with sports participation involving a longitudinal force with the foot in plantarflexion with a medial or lateral rotational force. The patient presents with complaint of midfoot pain with weight-bearing, following an acute injury. The pain worsens by forefoot weight bearing, and the patient may describe pain or difficulty with the push-off phases of walking and/or running. There is pain with abduction and eversion of the forefoot. Pain can also commonly be reproduced with passive pronation or supination of the tarsometatarsal joint. Radiographic findings show misalignment of the lateral margin of the first metatarsal base with the lateral edge of the medial cuneiform, misalignment of the medial aspect of the second metatarsal base with the medial edge of the middle cuneiform, and/or small avulsion fragments a one of metatarsal or cuneiform bones. On oblique view, the medial aspect of the cuboid should line up with the medial aspect of the fourth metatarsal base. The dorsal cortex of the first metatarsal and medial cuneiform should be aligned on the lateral radiographs. Lisfranc injuries can be managed operatively. Initial treatment includes reduction, splinting, and elevation. After six weeks, if the patient is non-tender and radiographs are negative, then begin weight-bearing and rehabilitation. If there is any tenderness but no displacement, then the patient should be in a boot or cast for at least another four weeks before starting rehabilitation. Any displacement requires surgical fixation.

 

 

Option B. Jones fracture. A Jones fracture is a fracture of the proximal metadiaphyseal junction of the fifth metatarsal bone that involves the 4th-5th metatarsal articulation. The fracture occurs as a result of significant adduction force to the forefoot with the ankle in plantar flexion. On a plain radiograph, Jones fracture is located at the metadiaphyseal junction, approximately 2 cm (1.5-3 cm) from the tip of the 5th metatarsal and has a predominantly horizontal course. It should not extend distally. Jones fractures are particularly prone to non-union due to being in a vascular watershed zone and take longer than two months to heal. Displacement of the fracture can increase with persistent weight-bearing; therefore, immobilization is important, with a non-weight bearing cast for 6-8 weeks. Indications for non-operative management include undisplaced fractures and fractures in patients with limited activity (i.e. recreational athletes). Operative management is indicated in patients that are elite or competitive athletes or when delayed union has occurred. Management includes either intramedullary screw fixation or open reduction and internal fixation. 

 

 

Option D. Nutcracker fracture. A nutcracker fracture refers to a cuboid bone fracture with associated navicular avulsion fracture due to compression between the bases of 4th and 5th metatarsals and calcaneus bone. The injury usually occurs secondary to the traumatic abduction of the forefoot. This results in loss of the normal lateral column support and excess valgus force upon the medial column that commonly causes rupture of tibialis posterior tendon or avulsion fracture of its attachment onto medial aspect of the tarsal navicular bone. Nutcracker fractures are clinically significant because they can interfere with the medchanical alignment of the foot.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Shint splint or stress fracture of tibia is the most common injury in runners.

questions.text: Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Inflammation without purulent discharge

 

MULTIFOCAL NON-SUPPURATIVE OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Focal sterile inflammatory disease with prolonged, self-limiting and recurring episodes.
  • It is an auto-inflammatory disorder that causes bone pain due to inflammation in the bones not caused by infection. 
  • It has been associated with SAPHO syndrome (Synovitis, Acne, Pustulosis, palmo-plantar Hyperostosis and Osteitis).
  • Clinical features:
    • Tenderness in affected area
    • Some patients may develop arthritis
    • Fatigue
    • Chronic pain affecting quality of life
    • Delayed growth in some children
    • Night bone pain
    • Regional palpable swelling over bones with little overlying soft tissue
       
  • Despite the local and systemic signs of inflammation, there is no purulent discharge and microbes are seldom isolated. This is a diagnosis of exclusion.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Mildly elevated CRP and ESR
    • Positive ANA and HLA-B27
    • Elevated serum cytokines
    • Mildly elevated serum TNF-alpha and IL-6
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • X-ray shows lytic bone lesions, sclerosis and hyperostosis.
    • MRI is the investigation of choice
    • Whole body MRI provides information about lesion distribution, soft tissue involvement, and/or possible involvement of additional organs
    • Bone biopsy reveals dense infiltrates of immune cells, bone lysis, fibrosis, and/or normal bone.
       
  • Treatment:
    • NSAIDs are first-line agents for quick symptomatic relief and control inflammation
    • Corticosteroids, DMARDs, anti-TNF agents, and bisphosphonates are effective in some patients

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Multifocal non-suppurative osteomyelitis is characterized by inflammation without any purulent discharge.

choices.text: High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Nutritional Rickets? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) High Urine Calcium to Creatinine Ratio

 

NUTRITIONAL RICKETS

 

  • In nutritional rickets, the calcium to creatinine ratio in urine is generally low instead of high. 

  • This occurs because rickets is the result of a lack of vitamin D, calcium, or phosphate, resulting in inadequate mineralization of bone. 

  • In reaction to conserve calcium levels, the body elevates the secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) and the kidneys actively reabsorb calcium, resulting in low urinary excretion of calcium and phosphate. 

  • Thus, the ratio of calcium to creatinine in urine is not elevated in nutritional rickets, reflecting calcium conservation.

  • A high urine calcium to creatinine ratio would suggest hypercalciuria, which is characteristic of conditions like hyperparathyroidismwithout underlying vitamin D deficiency, or certain renal tubular disorders, but not nutritional rickets.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal Serum Calcium: In nutritional rickets, vitamin D deficiency initially leads to decreased calcium absorption and a tendency for low serum calcium. This activates the compensatory mechanism of the body. The drop in serum calcium stimulates the parathyroid glands to release more parathyroid hormone (PTH). PTH then acts to increase calcium reabsorption in the kidneys, and mobilizes calcium from the bones (resorption). This helps to maintain serum calcium levels within the normal range, at the expense of bone health. So, it is common to see normal serum calcium in many cases of nutritional rickets.

 

Option B. Elevated Parathyroid Hormone: In rickets, parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels are frequently increased (secondary hyperparathyroidism) as the body attempts to counteract low calcium levels by enhancing calcium resorption from bones and kidneys. This is a hallmark of nutritional rickets and is the body's attempt to maintain calcium homeostasis.

 

Option C. Low Serum Phosphorus: A key feature of nutritional rickets is decreased serum phosphorus resulting from compromised renal phosphate reabsorption, exacerbated by a deficiency of vitamin D. High levels of parathyroid hormone (PTH) have a significant effect on phosphate metabolism. PTH causes the kidneys to excrete more phosphate in the urine. This leads to hypophosphatemia, which directly impairs the mineralization of new bone and cartilage, leading to the characteristic bone deformities of rickets.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Nutritional rickets is characterized by low vitamin D, leading to compensatory high PTH, which helps maintain normal serum calcium (often), but causes low serum phosphorus and, importantly, low urine calcium excretion due to renal calcium conservation.

  • A low UCa/Cr ratio is more commonly associated with nutritional rickets.

  • However, a high UCa/Cr ratio is not entirely uncommon and might reflect specific underlying mechanisms in some cases.

  • Therefore, the UCa/Cr ratio in nutritional rickets can vary depending on the specific situation.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to OPD with complaint of painless lump in left knee. X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Osteochondroma

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is a developmental malformation and not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodule.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap, a result of development malformation.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation, fracture through stalk or pedunculated (narrow based) lesion, sarcomatous change and Impingement of neighboring structure, e.g. nerve, vessel, etc.
  • The physical finding usually is a palpable mass.
  • Treatment: en bloc resection – extra-periosteal resection

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Enchondroma is a benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand. They are the chondromas that usually arise in the medullary canal. They are treated with extended curettage.

 

 

Option B. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option C. Osteoclastoma is located at the epiphysis. The most common location is distal femur, followed by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. Patient presents with swelling and vague pain. Radiographic examination reveals bony swelling, eccentrically located at the end of the bone and soap bubble appearance on X-ray. Radiographically, the lesions are purely lytic. The lesion frequently expands or breaks through the cortex, however, intraarticular extension is rare as the subchondral bone usually remains intact. Treatment is done by extended curettage by PMMA or phenol or liquid nitrogen and bone grafting – the procedure of choice. 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Osteochondromas are developmental malformations rather than true neoplasms that are usually painless.
  • The pain can be due to bursitis (most common).
  • The physical finding is usually a palpable mass.

questions.text: A patient complains that he often gets troubled at night during sleep by tingling and numbness that involves his lateral three digits. He further explains that symptoms are relieved as he lays his arms hanging from the bed. Correct regarding the condition is: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CTS: Durkan test

 

CARPAL TUNNEL SYNDROME

 

  • It is the entrapment of median nerve at the wrist beneath the flexor retinaculum
  • Clinical features:
    • 8 times more common in females
    • Usual age group is 50 years
    • Burning pain, paresthesia, tingling and numbness in median nerve distribution



       
    • Pain increased by activities, more troublesome at night; relieved by handing the arm over the side of bed or by shaking the arm
    • Clumsiness and weakness in tasks requiring fine manipulation
       
  • Special tests:
    • Sensory symptoms can be reproduced by percussion over the median nerve – Tinel’s sign
    • Sensory symptoms can also be reproduced by holding the wrist in full flexion for a minute – Phalen’s test/Reverse Phalen’s test

 

 

1. Phalen’s test; 2. Reverse Phalen’s test

 

  • The most specific test for carpal tunnel syndrome is Durkans test – Direct compression over the median nerve – best clinical test – done by holding wrist in slight flexion and directly compressing the nerve by applying pressure to proximal wrist crease for 30 seconds – development of pain, paresthesia or numbness indicates a positive test.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. CTS: Froment sign. Froment’s sign is seen in cases of ulnar nerve palsy where the adductor pollicis is paralysed. The patient is made to hold a book between the thumb and the palm. In case of ulnar nerve palsy, the patient will hold the book using the flexor pollicis longus muscle, which will produce flexion at the IP joint.

 

 

This sign is specific of ulnar nerve palsy and will be negative in carpal tunnel syndrome.

 

Option C. Guyon canal syndrome: Froment sign. Guyon Canal syndrome, also known as Ulnar Tunnel Syndrome/ulnar tunnel syndrome/handlebar palsy, is a relatively rare peripheral ulnar neuropathy. It is defined as a compression of the distal ulnar nerve at the level of the wrist as it enters the hand through a space called ulnar tunnel or Guyon canal. The clinical presentation can be purely sensory, purely motor or both depending on the location of the nerve compression. Froment’s sign will be positive in this case.

 

Option D. Guyon canal syndrome: Durkan test. Durkan test is the most specific and sensitive for carpal tunnel syndrome only.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given clinical symptoms of the patient suggest presence of carpal tunnel syndrome. The most specific test to check median nerve compression in the carpal tunnel is the Durkan’s Test.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with history of fever with bloody diarrhea 2 weeks back, followed by swollen, red and erythematous joints. What is the likely cause? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shigella

 

REACTIVE ARTHRITIS/REITER’S SYNDROME

 

  • The patient presents with a classic picture of reactive arthritis. 

  • Reactive arthritis is precipitated by antecedent gastrointestinal and genitourinary infections and manifests as an asymmetric sterile oligoarthritis, typically of the lower extremities.

  • Reactive arthritis occurs most commonly in young men and is associated with HLA-B27 in 80% of patients.

  • Etiopathogenesis:

    • Most cases of reactive arthritis develop within 1-4 weeks after either a gastrointestinal infection (usually with Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, or Campylobacter) or a sexually transmitted infection (with Chlamydia trachomatis or perhaps Ureaplasma urealyticum).

  • Clinical Features:

    • The arthritis is most commonly asymmetric and frequently involves the large weight-bearing joints (chiefly the knee and ankle). 

    • Sacroiliitis or ankylosing spondylitis is observed in at least 20% of patients, especially after frequent recurrences.

    • Triad: Arthritis + Conjunctivitis + Urethritis/Cervivitis (in females)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rotavirus. Rotavirus is a common cause of viral gastroenteritis, particularly in infants and young children. Typical symptoms among children with rotavirus infection include vomiting; watery, non-bloody diarrhea; and fever. In severe cases, dehydration, seizures, and death can occur. It is not commonly associated with reactive arthritis.

 

Option C. E.coli. While some strains of E. coli (like enterohemorrhagic E. coli O157:H7) can cause bloody diarrhea, and some E. coli infections have been linked to reactive arthritis, Shigella is more classically and frequently associated with it, especially given the history of fever and bloody diarrhea.

 

Option D. Giardia. Giardia is a parasite that causes giardiasis, characterized by watery, foul-smelling diarrhea, gas, and abdominal cramps. It is not typically associated with reactive arthritis. Inflammatory arthritis has been described following enteric infections with Giardia sp. The interval between the preceding infection and the manifestation of arthritis is 2-4 weeks. Post-infectious arthritis has a predilection for joints of the lower limbs particularly the knee and ankle. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Joint infection can occur as a manifestation of gastrointestinal infection from pathogen Shigella. 

  • This is most commonly found, and is called reactive arthritis, which causes joint swelling, pain and erythema. 

  • It is commonly associated with HLA B27.

questions.text: A suspect of sexual assault of 18 years of age claims to be of 16 years. X-rays of which area can confirm the correct age of the suspect? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D)  Knee and wrist

 

To determine the accurate age of a person based on bone ossification, certain joints are examined through X-rays. The ossification of specific bones indicates different age groups. The wrist and knee typically ossify by the age of 18, while other joints, such as the elbow, ossify by the age of 16. In this case, the suspect is claiming to be 16 years old, but if X-rays of both the knee and wrist show full ossification, this would confirm that the suspect is actually 18 years old. This is because these areas would not be fully ossified at 16 but would be ossified at 18, matching the age of the suspect.

 

For 18 years of age:

 

 

For 16 years of age:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Elbow and hip: The elbow and hip ossify by the age of 16. If these joints were ossified, it would support the suspect's claim of being 16 years old, which would not be useful in confirming that they are 18.

 

Option B. Elbow and wrist: The elbow ossifies at 16, but the wrist ossifies at 18. This combination would not be conclusive for determining that the suspect is 18 years old.

 

Option C. Knee and elbow: The elbow ossifies at 16, while the knee ossifies at 18. Similar to option B, this combination would be ambiguous and not definitive for confirming that the suspect is 18.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The ossification of the wrist and knee is a reliable indicator of whether an individual is 18 years old, as both these areas ossify by that age.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presents with swelling in the right femur for 6 months. He complaints of severe pain in the thigh which dramatically improves with intake of aspirin. The biopsy image from the lesion is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoid osteoma

 

  • This benign bone tumor is smaller in size, usually < 2 cm, and is commonly located in the cortex of long bones.
  • Femoral diaphysis is the most common location.
  • It is characterized histologically by a nidus surrounded by sclerotic bone.
  • A unique feature is that the pain worsens at night and gets a dramatic relief with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), such as aspirin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option. A. Osteosarcoma: A malignant tumor characterized by the direct formation of bone or osteoid tissue by tumor cells. It often appears in the metaphysis of long bones such as the femur, tibia, and humerus, primarily affecting children and young adults. Almost all patients with high-grade osteosarcoma report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis. May respond to NSAIDs like aspirin, but the response is often transient. Histologically, osteoid production from the tumor cells is seen. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.

 

 

Option. C. Osteochondroma: A common benign bone growth that consists of a cartilage-capped bony projection or outgrowth on the surface of bones (exostosis). It typically arises from the metaphysis near the growth plate of long bones, particularly around the knee and shoulder. Usually asymptomatic, but may cause pain if the tumor becomes large or if it irritates nearby structures. Pathology and histology of an osteochondroma reveal a cap of benign hyaline cartilage resembling a disorganized growth plate, covered peripherally by perichondrium.

 

 

Option. D. Ewing's Sarcoma: A highly aggressive, malignant bone tumor that affects mostly children and adolescents. It can occur in any bone but is most often found in long bones and the pelvic region. Histologically, it features small, round, blue cells. Typically presents with pain, swelling, and a palpable mass. May respond to NSAIDs, but the response is often transient.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The distinctive clinical presentation of relief with aspirin strongly points to an osteoid osteoma, especially when correlated with the biopsy findings suggestive of this benign condition.

questions.text: Identify the deformity shown in the image:(FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cubitus valgus

 

CUBITUS VALGUS

 

  • Cubitus valgus is increased carrying angle which leads to displacement of the distal part away from the midline.
  • Carrying angle is the angle between long axis of arm and forearm. Its normal value is 5-15°.

 

 

  • Cubitus valgus is ost commonly caused by non-union of fracture around the elbow.
  • Lateral condyle fracture humerus is known for non-union and it involves growth plate hence, it causes cubitus valgus that can be progressive. In lateral condyle humerus fracture, cubitus valgus is much more common than varus.
  • Tardy ulnar nerve palsy is a late complication of progressive cubitus valgus.
  • The excision of head of radius in children may also produce cubitus valgus deformity and instability.
  • Treatment of cubitus valgus is by Milch Osteotomy with stable fixation using plates and screws.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gun stock deformity. Gun stock deformity or Cubitus Varus is reduced carrying angle in the elbow. It is most commonly seen in cases of malunion of fractures around the elbow. Supracondylar humerus fracture malunion is the most common cause of this deformity. As the fracture occurs above the growth plate, so it causes a static varus deformity. Lateral condyle fracture very rarely undergoes malunion. If this happens, there occurs a progressive cubitus

 

 

Option C. Coxa vara. It is the reduced angle between neck and shaft of femur due to some growth anomaly at upper femoral epiphysis (infantile type) or secondary to various other pathologies (acquired). The normal femoral neck shaft angle is 160° at birth, decreasing to 135 degrees in adult life. An angle of <120 degrees is called coxa vara. Congenital coxa vara can be due to congenital femoral deficiency, or developmental coxa vara. Acquired coxa vara can be due to SCFE, as a sequelae of AVN of femoral epiphysis, Perthes disease, femoral neck fracture, intertrochanteric fracture, rickets

 

 

Option D. Coxa valga. Coxa valga describes a deformity of the hip where there is an increased angle between the femoral neck and femoral shaft. It is often associated with shallow acetabular angles and femoral head subluxation. Coxa valga occurs when the angle formed between the neck of the femur and its shaft is increased beyond >140º. Normal is between 125-135º in adults, but can be 20-25º greater at birth and 10º greater in children. When the angle is <120º, this is considered coxa vara.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deformity shown in the image given in the question is called cubitus valgus which is the increase in the carrying angle. It is caused most commonly by non union of fracture around the elbow.

questions.text: Identify the condition:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Brodie’s abscess

 

BRODIE’S ABSCESS

 

  • It is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone (long standing because of strong defence mechanism of body)
  • Seen in immunocompetent host.
  • This intraosseous abscess is related to subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.
  • It usually involves long bones (metaphysis or diaphysis); e.g., Upper end of tibia
  • Classical Brodie’s abscess looks like a small walled off (sclerotic margins) cavity in bone with little or no periosteal reaction.

 

 

  • Usual isolated organism is Staphylococcus aureus (although most cultures are negative)
  • Treatment: Trial of injectable antibiotics is given; if it fails, curettage of the cavity is carried out.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Intra-cortical hemangioma. Hemangioma of bone is a benign tumor that usually involves a vertebra or the skull and commonly is found as an incidental asymptomatic lesion.  They are slightly less commonly encountered in men (M:F = 0.7:1) and most commonly seen in the 5th decade of life but can occur at any age. These tumors are slow-growing and are most commonly asymptomatic unless they exert mass effect on sensitive structures, present as a swelling or a palpable mass, especially in the skull. Most commonly, they are located in the thoracic spine, followed by the skull and facial bones, followed by long bones where they preferentially involve the metaphysis or diaphysis.

 

 

Hemangioma of proximal femur

 

Option D. Chondromyxoid fibroma. Chondromyxoid fibroma is a rare lesion of cartilaginous origin. Although chondromyxoid fibromas may occur at any age, most commonly occur in patients of 10-30 years old. Any bone may be involved, but the proximal tibia is the most common location. In contrast to other cartilaginous lesions, radiographic evidence of intralesional calcification usually is absent. Treatment consists of resection or extended curettage.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The given image shows Brodie’s abscess, which is a long standing localized pyogenic abscess in the bone, seen in subacute or chronic pyogenic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: A patient suffered from tibial fracture following a road traffic accident. He complained of pain on passive flexion. His posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulses were palpable, but he had loss of sensation in the 1st webspace. What will be the next step? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measure anterior compartment pressure

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
       
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign
    • Order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
    • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm. The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.
       
  • The general indications for fasciotomy are:
    • Impending tissue ischemia
    • When the tissue pressure reaches 30 mm Hg or the difference between diastolic blood pressure and compartment pressure is less than 30 mm Hg (Normal compartment pressure is 8-10 mm Hg and pressure at calf during walking is 200-300 mm Hg).
       
  • A higher pressure is a strong indication that fasciotomy should be recommended.
  • In a hypotensive patient, the acceptable pressure is lower.

 

Extra Edge:

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Reapply cast. Application of cast will further put pressure on the leg compartments. So, this treatment method will not help.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In this clinical scenario, the pain on passive flexion is the first sign of compartment syndrome. Pulselessness is the late feature. So it is advised to measure the compartment pressure first.

questions.text: A 65-year-old post-menopausal female came with persistent back ache, not responding to conservative treatment. She has a history of heavy weight lifting 4 months back with progressively increasing pain that worsens on walking and starts radiating down her legs within 100m range of walking, she however feels no pain on climbing up the stairs. Most probable diagnosis is? (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lumbar canal stenosis

 

LUMBAR CANAL STENOSIS

 

  • Lumbar spinal stenosis is a narrowing of the spinal canal, compressing the nerves travelling through the lower back into the legs.
  • While it may affect younger patients, due to developmental causes, it is more often a degenerative condition that affects people who are typically age 60 and older.
  • Narrowing of the spinal canal usually occurs slowly, over many years or decades.
  • Degenerative spondylosis is a significant etiology of lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • The discs become less spongy with aging, resulting in loss of disc height, and may cause bulging of the hardened disc into the spinal canal.
  • Bone spurs may also occur and ligaments may thicken.
  • All of these can contribute to narrowing of the central canal and may or may not produce symptoms.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis is another cause of lumbar spinal stenosis. When degenerative changes of the spine occur, the pars interarticularis can be fractured, and the resulting instability can lead to forward translation of the vertebra.  Sufficient anterior slippage of one vertebra on the next vertebral segment can narrow the spinal canal, leading to stenosis.
  • When the lateral recess and neural foramen are stenosed, symptoms of lumbar radiculopathy may also present.
  • Classification (anatomic):
    • Central stenosis: caused by hypertrophied ligamentaum flavum anteriorly and bulging disc posteriorly with consequent thecal sac compression
    • Lateral recess stenosis: due to facet joint arthropathy with overgrowth of the superior articular facet and osteophyte formation. This results in compression of the descending nerve roots.
    • Foraminal stenosis: due to loss of disc height, foraminal disc protrusion, or osteophyte formation with resultant compression of the exiting nerve root.
    • Extraforaminal stenosis: due to far lateral disc herniation again with resultant exiting nerve root compression 
  • Symptoms may be due to inflammation, compression of the nerve(s) or both.
  • Such symptoms may include:
    • Pain, weakness or numbness in the legs, calves or buttocks, exacerbated by prolonged ambulation, standing, and with lumbar extension, and is relieved by forward flexion and rest.
    • Neurogenic claudication is an important feature. Symptoms are bilateral, but usually asymmetric. Low back pain, numbness, and tingling are present.
    • Cramping in the calves with walking, requiring frequent short rests to walk a distance
    • Pain radiating into one or both thighs and legs, similar to the lay term “sciatica”
    • In rare cases, loss of motor functioning of the legs, loss of normal bowel or bladder function
    • Pain may improve with bending forward, sitting or lying down.
    • Walking upstairs being easier than walking downstairs, as the back is forward flexed with stairs climbing.
    • If patients present with new-onset bowel or bladder dysfunction, saddle anesthesia, bilateral lower extremity weakness, and/or increased lower extremity, the patient may have developed cauda equina or conus medullaris syndromes. 
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis and degenerative scoliosis are two conditions that may be associated with lumbar spinal stenosis.
  • Degenerative spondylolisthesis (slippage of one vertebra over another) is caused by osteoarthritis of the facet joints. Most commonly, it involves the L4 slipping over the L5 vertebra. It is usually treated with the same non-surgical (“conservative”) and surgical methods as lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Investigations:
    • MRI of the lumbosacral spine is the modality of choice for lumbar spinal stenosis, and CT myelography is an option when MRI is contraindicated.
    • Anteroposterior spinal canal diameters of less than 10 mm are also frequently used for the diagnosis of lumbar spinal stenosis. 
  • Treatment:
    • Management for lumbar spinal stenosis aims at reducing symptoms and improving functional status. 
    • Conservative treatment is the first-line treatment for this condition. 
    • Conservative treatment options include physical therapy, oral anti-inflammatory medications, and epidural steroid injections.
    • The most frequently performed surgical procedure is a laminectomy (Wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression). This is usually indicated in cases of ongoing pain despite conservative measures for 3-6 months and where there is progressive neurologic deterioration e.g. motor weakness, bowel and/or bladder dysfunction.
    • Laminectomy with fusion (wide pedicle-to-pedicle decompression with instrumented fusion) is indicated when further stability is required, which is done in patients with concurrent segmental instability e.g. spondylolisthesis (degenerative or isthmic) or degenerative scoliosis.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A. Vertebral osteoporotic compression fracture. These are very common fragility fractures of the spine that affect up to 50% of people over 80 years old. The patient complains of pain localized to area of fracture. There is focal tenderness or pain with deep palpation of spinous process. Radiographs will show loss of anterior, middle, or posterior vertebral height by 20% or at least 4mm. Treatment is usually non-operative. If the fracture is less than five days old, calcitonin can be used for four weeks to decrease pain. Bisphosphonates can be given to prevent future risk of fragility fractures. Some patients may benefit from an extension orthosis. Surgical options may include vertebroplasty, kyphoplasty, surgical decompression and stabilization.

 

 

Option B. PIVD. A herniated disc in the spine is a condition during which a nucleus pulposus is displaced from intervertebral space. It is a common cause of back pain. Herniated disc pain often presents with burning sensation, and may radiate into the lower extremity. Furthermore, in more severe cases, there can be associated with weakness or sensation changes. The disc prolapse can be very painful. Within a few weeks, most cases heal. In many instances, it does not cause that patient any pain. They are often seen on MRI of asymptomatic patients. The initial treatment should be conservative, unless a patient has severe neurological compromise. Surgery is usually the last resort. Physical therapy is the key for most patients.

 

 

Option D. Isthmic spondylolisthesis. Spondylolisthesis occurs when there is an anterior translation or “slippage” of one vertebral body relative to its caudal vertebral body. In most cases, symptoms associated with spondylolisthesis are chronic.  The primary symptom of chronic spondylolisthesis is back pain, with or without leg pain. Isthmic spondylolisthesis refers to a defect in the pars interarticularis that results in anterior subluxation over time, most commonly at L5-S1 followed by L4-5. The resulting anterior subluxation can produce back pain, central canal stenosis, and lateral recess or foraminal stenosis. The most common etiology for isthmic spondylolisthesis is instability of unilateral or bilateral pars interarticularis. The most common symptom of presentation is low back pain, which may be mechanical in nature, depressed deep tendon reflexes, positive straight leg signs, and diminished sensations. Isthmic spondylolisthesis with low back pain should initially be managed conservatively. Surgical treatment options consist of decompression of the neural elements alone versus decompression with internal fixation for bony fusion to prevent further subluxation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A back pain that worsens on walking and radiates down the legs within 100m of walking, and that does not occur on climbing up the stairs, is suggestive of lumbar canal stenosis where the pain relieves on forward bending the trunk, as in climbing the stairs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was brought to emergency after sustaining a fall on his outstretched hand. On examination, there was swelling and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. He was managed by applying a cast as shown below. What is the likely fracture? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Scaphoid Fracture

 

  • Given scenario and image showing a Glass Holding Cast, most likely depicts a Scaphoid Fracture.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. It is an extra-articular fracture of lower end of radius at its cortico-cancellous junction. It presents with the classical Dinner fork deformity.

 

 

 

Most Colle’s fractures can be successfully treated non-operatively and a Hand-shaking cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization in Colle’s fracture is:

 

 

Option C. Smith fracture. Smith fracture is reverse Colle’s and there is garden spade deformity due to malunion. It is an extra articular fracture of the distal radius featuring a volar displacement or angulation of the distal fragment.

 

 

The mainstay of treatment of undisplaced and stable distal radius fractures is closed reduction followed by immobilization. It is treated by close reduction and immobilization in above elbow cast with forearm in supination and wrist in extension (dorsiflexion).

 

 

Option D. Galeazzi fracture. The combination of fracture of the distal third of the shaft of the radius and dislocation of the distal radioulnar joint (along with damage to interosseous membrane and Triangular Fibro Cartilage complex) is called Galeazzi Fracture dislocation (the fracture of necessity). A treatment regimen of closed reduction and cast immobilization has a high rate of unsatisfactory results. Open reduction and internal fixation with plate is the treatment of choice in adult.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the treatment of undisplaced and stable scaphoid fractures, a glass-holding cast is applied.

questions.text: Patellar Clunk Syndrome scar is present at superior pole of patella and impinging on: (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral component during extension

 

PATELLAR CLUNK SYNDROME

 

  • It is knee popping and catching due to fibrous nodule on superior pole of patella in TKR patients that impinges on femoral component on knee extension.
  • If symptoms are severe, it requires resection of fibrous nodule (arthroscopic/open).
  • Patients complain of a clunking during knee extension, caused by a suprapatellar fibrous nodule that interferes with patella movement.
  • There is an accumulation of scar tissue along the undersurface of the quadriceps tendon, proximal to the superior pole of the patella.
  • The cause of scar tissue is unknown, but may be related to:
    • Direct trauma to quadriceps tendon during patella resection during TKR
    • Impingement of the quadriceps tendon on the femoral component due to an undersized patellar component
  • Scar is entrapped within the intercondylar notch during flexion.
  • It impinges on the femoral component and is forced out of the notch during active knee extension.
  • The painful snap or clunk is usually felt between 30-45 degrees
  • Many patients can be managed without surgery.
  • However, if there are persistent symptoms, surgical excision of the nodule can be useful.

 

OTHER SOFT TISSUE DISORDERS

 

  • Irritation of the lateral facet of the patella: Contact between the lateral facet of the patella and the femoral implant, in the region of the lateral condyle, can cause chronic lateral knee pain.
  • Popliteal Tendon Impingement: After TKA, the popliteal tendon can be irritated by overhand of the femoral condyles, from a posterolateral osteophyte, from residual synovium or extruded cement. Patients complain of discrete posterior knee pain that occurs after a specific point of knee flexion.
  • Protruding Medial Tibial Component: Pain along the medial knee can be from the protrusion of the tibial, including medial collateral ligament irritation. Tibial revision is necessary if pain is intolerable.
  • Nerve Injury: Deep peroneal nerve injury is a rare but reported complication of TKA, caused by compression, ischemia, traction, crush, or laceration. It typically occurs when there is surgical correction of a significant preoperative valgus deformity or flexion contracture of the knee. The infrapatellar branch of the saphenous nerve (IBSN) is commonly affected after knee replacement. Patients can report numbness (sometimes a painful numbness) along the lateral aspect of the knee for over a year.
  • Complex Regional Pain Syndrome: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome is a very rare consequence of knee replacement. It is characterized by pain disproportionate to exam findings. There is sensory disturbance (e.g., pain evoked by light brushing of the skin, called allodynia), motor impairment (e.g., weakness), and sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., edema, color changes).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The scar of the patellar clunk syndrome after TKR is present at the superior pole of the patella and it impinges on the femoral component of the implant of active knee extension.

questions.text:
A woman presented with morning stiffness that gradually resolves over one hour. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this condition? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

  1. NSAIDs can improve the symptoms and have disease modifying activity.
  2. Absence of erosion rules out the diagnosis.
  3. It is associated with raised ESR and CRP.
  4. HLA DR4 is related to the prognosis
questions.solution:
Ans. D) III, IV are correct

 

RHEUMATOID ARTHRITIS

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis is a chronic non-suppurative inflammation of the synovial joints.
  • Clinical Features:
    • It occurs between the age of 20 and 50 years.
    • Women are affected about 3 times more commonly than men.
    • Older women (> 60 year) are 6 times more commonly involved than younger one.
    • It may present as:
      • An acute, symmetrical polyarthritis
      • Pain and stiffness in multiple joints (at least four), particularly in the morning, mark the beginning of the disease.
      • This may be followed by frank symptoms of articular inflammation.
      • The joints affected most commonly are the metacarpophalangeal joints, particularly that of the index finger.
         
  • Joints affected in Rheumatoid arthritis:
    • Common: MCP joints of hand, PIP joints of fingers, wrists, knees, elbows, ankles, MTP joint
    • Less common: Hip joint, temporo mandibular joint
    • Uncommon: Atlanto-axial joint, facet joints of cervical spine
    • Usually DIP is not involved in and is not used for diagnosis but is involved when swan neck and boutonniere deformity develops.
    • Lumbar Spine is usually spared.
       
  • The onset may be with fever, the cause of which cannot be established (PUO), especially in children.
  • Sometimes, visceral manifestations of the disease such as pneumonitis, rheumatoid nodules etc. may antedate the joint complaints.
  • Inflammatory markers like ESR and CRP are elevated.
  • Some studies have shown that HLA DR4 positivity affects the prognosis.
  • Deformities in Rheumatoid Arthritis:

 

 

  • Radiological Features:
    • Reduced joint space
    • Erosion of articular margins
    • Subchondral cysts
    • Juxta-articular rarefaction
    • Soft tissue shadow at the level of the joint because of joint effusion or synovial hypertrophy
    • Deformities of the hand and fingers
       
  • Treatment:
    • Exercises to maintain muscle strength and joint mobility.
    • NSAIDs
    • Glucocorticoid therapy esp. in vasculitis.
    • Immunosuppressive therapy by leflunomide, DMARDs, methotrexate (drug of choice), anticytokine, etanercept, cyclosporine, infliximab, adalimumab, abatacept.

 

Other Options:

 

  • NSAIDs are anti-inflammatory drugs and not disease-modifying drugs. NSAIDs are used for symptomatic treatment in RA. They have few side effects but also have potential adverse effects like GI bleeding.
  • Bone erosion is a central feature of rheumatoid arthritis and is associated with disease severity and poor functional outcome. Erosion of periarticular cortical bone, the typical feature observed on plain radiographs in patients with rheumatoid arthritis, results from excessive local bone resorption and inadequate bone formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rheumatoid arthritis presents with raised serum ESR and quantitative CRP levels, and HLA DR4 positivity.

questions.text: Identify the implant shown in the image used for treatment of proximal femoral fracture. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dynamic hip screw

 

The image shows an implant used for the treatment of proximal femoral fractures, specifically intertrochanteric fractures. The implant depicted is a Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS), which is composed of two main components: a large screw (commonly referred to as a Richard screw) and a plate with a barrel. The screw slides within the barrel as the bone heals, allowing controlled movement and promoting bone union.

 

The DHS has been the gold standard for treating intertrochanteric fractures, especially extracapsular femoral neck fractures. It works by providing stability while allowing dynamic compression at the fracture site, which helps in bone healing. However, with advancements in medical technology, cephalomedullary nails (such as the proximal femoral nail) have largely replaced the DHS for such fractures in recent times.

 

Two types of proximal femoral fractures:

 

  1. Fracture of the neck of femur (intra-capsular):
    • Less than 65 years of age: Perform closed reduction (do not open) and fix with cannulated cancellous screw fixation (fixation with screws).
    • More than or equal to 65 years of age: Perform hemiarthroplasty (replace half the joint).
    • Any age with joint damage: Perform total hip replacement (for hip joint damage).
    • Neck of femur fracture is also referred to as the unsolved fracture.
  2. Intertrochanteric fractures:
    • Treatment options include the dynamic hip screw or proximal femoral fracture treatment.
    • Modern treatment involves placing nails:
      • Cephalomedullary or proximal femoral nail: A nail is placed inside the femur, with a screw into the head of the femur.
    • Fractures lower down: Treated with interlock nailing.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dynamic condylar plate: The dynamic condylar plate is primarily used for distal femoral fractures, not proximal femoral fractures like intertrochanteric fractures. It does not have the screw-barrel mechanism that is specific to the dynamic hip screw.

 

Option C. Dynamic trochanteric plate: While similar-sounding, the dynamic trochanteric plate is not commonly used for intertrochanteric fractures. The DHS is more specifically designed for dynamic compression in such cases.

 

Option D. Limited contact condylar plate: This plate is generally used for fractures that require minimal disturbance of the periosteum, but it is not typically used for intertrochanteric fractures, which require dynamic fixation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Dynamic Hip Screw (DHS) is a two-part implant, featuring a screw and a plate, and is used to treat intertrochanteric fractures of the proximal femur.

questions.text: What to be done next? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Bone biopsy

 

  • The given X-ray image shows a bone tumor which needs to be diagnosed.
  • The image shows a well-defined, lytic lesion (a darker area indicating bone destruction) in the distal femur, specifically in the medial femoral condyle. 
  • The lesion appears somewhat expansile and has a narrow zone of transition, suggesting a benign or low-grade aggressive lesion rather than a highly aggressive malignant tumor. 
  • There's no clear periosteal reaction or soft tissue mass immediately evident.
  • This appearance is highly suggestive of a Giant Cell Tumor (GCT), given its typical location (epiphyseal/metaphyseal region of long bones), lytic nature, and often eccentric appearance. 
  • Other possibilities might include an aneurysmal bone cyst or a chondroblastoma, but GCT is a strong consideration.
  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • Bone biopsy is the most appropriate "next step" to definitively diagnose the nature of the lesion before proceeding with a potentially complex surgical intervention.
  • Without a biopsy, one cannot be absolutely certain of the benign or malignant nature, or the specific type of tumor.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extended curettage with allograft. Curettage involves scraping out the tumor. "Extended" curettage aims to remove as much of the tumor as possible while preserving the bone. After removal, the resulting cavity often needs to be filled to maintain structural integrity. An allograft is one option for filling. This is a common treatment for GCTs, especially those that are not highly aggressive or are in a location where wide excision would lead to significant functional impairment. Extended curettage remains the preferred treatment option for Grade I and II GCT due to least postoperative morbidity, cost-effectiveness, and surgical convenience. The risk of recurrence is high after curettage alone,and therefore adjuvants such as cryosurgery, cement, phenol or a combination of these are recommended. 

 

Option C. Curettage. Curettage alone might be insufficient for a lesion like a GCT due to its tendency for local recurrence. Compared with resection, curettage is associated with a higher rate of local recurrence; however, curettage often allows for a better functional result. Curettage can be extended by the use of adjuvants, such as liquid nitrogen, phenol, polymethylmethacrylate (PMMA), or thermal cautery to extend destruction of tumor cells. Bone cavities have been reinforced with autologous bone grafts, allograft, PMMA bone cement, demineralized bone matrix and bone graft substitutes. These fillers augment final bone strength, reduce the risk of local recurrence (esp. giant cell tumors) and fill the empty cavities. 

 

Educational Objective:

  • To reach the correct and final diagnosis, a bone biopsy test must be done. 
  • The management will follow the result of the bone biopsy. 
  • If the question implies "what is the definitive treatment generally indicated for a lesion with this appearance (strongly suggesting GCT)," then options A or D would be relevant. Giant Cell Tumors are known for local recurrence after simple curettage, which is why extended curettage (with or without adjuvant therapy) is the preferred surgical treatment.

questions.text: Book test is for: (INICET NOVEMBER 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar nerve

 

TESTS FOR ULNAR NERVE PALSY

 

  • Froment sign/book test: Hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch. This indicates a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

 

 

  • Jeanne sign: Reciprocal hyperextension of the thumb MCP joint indicating substitution of flexor pollicis longus (FPL) for adductor pollicis.

 

 

  • Wartenburg sign: Abduction of the small finger at MCP joint indicating deficient palmar intrinsic muscle (innervated by ulnar nerve) with abduction from extensor digiti minimi (innervated by the radial nerve).

 

 

  • Duchenne sign: Clawing of the ring and small fingers, hyperextension of MCP joints, and flexion of PIP joints indicating deficient interosseous and lumbrical muscles of the ring and small fingers.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Median nerve. Special tests for median nerve injury are:

 

  • Pen Test:
    • Test: Patient keeps his/her hand flat on the table and at the same time, examiner brings a pen above the thumb.
    • Interpretation: Patient tries to touch the pen by abduction the thumb and examiner feels the tendon of abductor pollicis brevis (APB) at the wrist. Patient fails to touch in APB paralysis and examiner will not be able to palpate the tendon.
    • Note: Median nerve invariably and exclusively supply APB.

 

 

  • Pointing Index Sign/Ochsner’s Clasping/Benediction Test:
    • Test: Patient clasps his both hand together.
    • Interpretation: The index finger fails to flex in median nerve injury and it points outward as pointing index.
    • Note: It occur in high median nerve palsy where flexor digitorum superficialis and lateral half of flexor digitorum profundus gets involved.

 

 

A. Pointing index; B. Benediction test

 

Option C. Posterior interosseous nerve. The patient may exhibit weakness with finger extension. When asked to make a fist, the wrist may deviate radially due to extensor carpi ulnaris weakness. Depending on injury severity there may be a positive Tinel sign at the site of injury.

 

Option D. Radial nerve. Special tests for radial nerve palsy are:

 

  • Wrist drop test:
    • The patient is asked to extend wrist with the elbow flexed 90°.
    • In radial nerve palsy affecting the wrist extensors, the patient will be unable to extend the wrist. The hand will hang down in a deformity known as a “wrist drop“.

 

 

a. Normal; b. Wrist drop

 

  • In a second stage of the test, the patient is asked to abduct the thumb.
  • In radial nerve palsy, the patient will be unable to abduct the thumb because of the paralysis of the abductor pollicis longus muscle and, to a lesser extent, the extensor pollicis brevis muscle.

 

 

a. Thumb abduction; b. Paralysis

 

  • Thumb extension test:
    • The examiner grasps the patient’s wrist with one hand and presses the thumb into adduction with the other hand.
    • Then the patient is asked to extend or abduct both the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints of the thumb.
    • Where this nerve is damaged, thumb extension will be weakened or impossible as a result of paralysis of the extensor pollicis longus and brevis.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal; c. Weak thumb extension

 

  • Supination test:
    • Supination Test evaluates compression neuropathy of the deep branch of the radial nerve.
    • The patient is seated, holding the elbow slightly flexed and the forearm pronated.
    • The elbow is held alongside the trunk to minimize motion in the shoulder.
    • The patient is then asked to supinate forearm, at first normally and then against the examiner’s resistance.
    • Weakness or loss of supination of the forearm is a sign of paresis of the supinator muscle, which is supplied by the deep branch of the radial nerve.

 

 

a. Starting position; b. Normal supination; c. Supination against resistance

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Book test is done for ulnar nerve palsy where there is hyperflexion of the thumb IP joint while attempting to pinch, indicating a substitution of flexor pollicis longus (innervated by median nerve) for adductor pollicis (innervated by ulnar nerve).

questions.text:
Arrange the following external fixators used for treatment of fracture of tibia in order of increasing stability: (INICET NOV 2021)

 

  1. Ilizarov

  2. Uniplanar frame with one rod

  3. Biplanar frame

  4. Uniplanar frame with two rods
questions.solution:
Ans. A. II, IV, III, I

 

EXTERNAL FIXATION

 

  • In External fixation, the fixation device is external to skin.

  • Uniplanar frame with one rod provides the least stability as it can only resist forces in one plane.

  • In uniplanar frame with two rods, adding a second rod increases stability compared to a single rod.

  • Biplanar frame provides stability in two planes, making it more secure than uniplanar frames. It improves the resistance to rotational and bending forces.

  • The Ilizarov external fixator is known for its exceptional stability due to its ring structure and multiple pins. It provides high axial and torsional stability.

  • It is often used for complex fractures and lengthening procedures.

  • Ilizarov fixator works on the principles of distraction osteogenesis i.e., an osteotomy is carried out and distracted at the rate of 1 mm per day causing distraction at the callus and subsequently lengthening can be done.

  • It can be used for correction of deformities like malunion, shortening, shortening with discharging sinus, gap non-union and also for CTEV.

  • Therefore, the Ilizarov fixator offers the highest level of stability among the options listed.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For the fixation of tibia fracture, the order of external fixators used in order of increased stability is:

 

Uniplanar frame with one rod (II) < uniplanar frame with two rods (IV) < biplanar frame (III) < ilizarov (I)

questions.text:
Which of the following statement/s is/are true regarding open fracture?(INICET MAY 2021)

 

  1. Compartment syndrome is rare.
  2. Immediate debridement should be done.
  3. Tibia is the most common long bone involved.
  4. Multiple fractures are uncommon.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) I, II & III are correct

 

I. Compartment syndrome is rare: True

 

  • In open fractures, the fascia may be disrupted, which reduces the risk of rising compartment pressure.

  • However, compartment syndrome can still occur, especially in high-energy injuries, so it is not impossible, but it is less common compared to closed fractures.

 

II. Immediate debridement should be done: True

 

  • Early and thorough surgical debridement is the cornerstone of open fracture management to reduce infection risk.

  • Ideally performed within 6–8 hours, though recent evidence suggests that a short delay may not significantly change infection rates if antibiotics are given promptly.

 

III. Tibia is the most common long bone involved: True

 

  • The tibia is the most commonly involved long bone in open fractures due to its subcutaneous location (minimal soft tissue coverage).

  • Therefore, it’s more vulnerable to open injuries, especially in road traffic accidents.

 

IV. Multiple fractures are uncommon: False

  • Multiple fractures are actually common, particularly in high-energy trauma like road traffic accidents, falls from height, or blast injuries.

  • Open fractures often occur as part of polytrauma.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • In open fracture, compartment syndrome is a rare entity as the fracture communicates with the surrounding atmosphere, preventing an increase in the compartment pressure.
  • These fractures need immediate irrigation with antibiotics and debridement of the wound.
  • Tibia is the most common site for open fractures after phalanges.

questions.text: A victim of road traffic accident (RTA) presents with fracture of hand with hypothenar atrophy. Nerve involved in him is: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ulnar nerve

 

  • In the hand, the ulnar nerve gives motor innervation to the hypothenar (palmaris brevis, abductor digiti minimi, flexor digiti minimi, opponens digiti minimi) and the thenar (adductor pollicis, deep head of flexor pollicis brevis) muscles. 
  • Also, it supplies the palmar and dorsal interossei and medial 2 lumbricals.
  • The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow and the wrist, resulting in motor and sensory loss.
  • Mechanisms of injury include trauma like motor vehicle accident; nerve impingement; lacerations at the wrist; and Guyon’s canal cyst.
  • A motor vehicle accident resulting in a fracture of the metacarpal or phalanges can lead to injury of the ulnar nerve.
  • This is indicated by the atrophy of the hypothenar muscles, leading to flattening of the hypothenar eminence. 
  • Other clinical features of ulnar nerve injury include:
    • Loss of hypothenar eminence
    • Loss of adduction of thumb
    • Loss of abduction of fingers
    • Clawing of 4th and 5th digits

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Radial nerve: The radial nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the forearm and hand. Injury to this nerve would typically result in wrist drop due to loss of extensor muscle function, not hypothenar atrophy. 

 

Option C. Musculocutaneous nerve: The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles in the upper arm. Its involvement would affect arm flexion and not the hypothenar muscles.

 

Option D. Median nerve: The median nerve supplies the thenar eminence and the first two lumbricals. Injury to this nerve would result in issues with thumb opposition and grip, but not hypothenar atrophy.

 

Additional Information: 

 

  • Flexor pollicis brevis superficial head is supplied by median nerve and deep head is supplied by ulnar nerve.
  • The first and second lumbricals are supplied by the median nerve.
  • The third and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • When the lumbricals are paralyzed, they can result in a deformity known as a "claw hand."
  • Ulnar or median nerve injury can lead to a deformity known as "claw hand."
  • Among these, ulnar nerve palsy is more commonly associated with claw hand.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypothenar atrophy is a clinical sign of ulnar nerve injury.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male complained of gradual swelling around the wrist for 3 months. X-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Giant cell tumor

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is the bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Only tumour that can involve the joints and cartilage
  • GCT has 2 types of cells:
    • Giant cells
    • Mononuclear cells: Malignant cells
       
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – A feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Osteoid osteoma. It is commonest benign true bone tumor. The patient has pain that is worse at night and is relieved by aspirin or other NSAID medications. When the lesion is in a vertebra, scoliosis may occur. Both Osteoblastic & Osteoclastic cells are seen. The lesion has central lysis with surrounding sclerosis. Growing center is called as Nidus (Seed). It is most common in diaphysis of femur. CT is the best study to identify the nidus and confirm the diagnosis. D/D of osteoid osteoma is bone island. Radiofrequency ablation is used for osteoid osteoma. Surgical management involves removal of the entire nidus done by burr-down technique.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The x-ray image shown in the question is diagnostic of Giant cell tumor of the distal end of radius.
  • Tumor of distal end radius is GCT, until proved otherwise.

choices.text: Tension band wiring with cancellous screws

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy was brought to emergency department with pain and swelling of right knee. A radiograph was taken as shown below. What is the best management for this patient? (FMGE JUNE 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tension band wiring with K-wires
