  • X-ray shows displaced patellar fracture, for which best treatment would be performing a Tension band wiring with K-wires.
  • Patellar Fracture occurs due to violent muscular pull (indirect) or direct trauma.

 

Treatment of Patellar Fracture:

 

  • Displaced transverse fracture: Tension Band Wiring by K-wire and stainless steel (ss) wire
  • Comminuted fracture: At least proximal third of patella is intact (partial patellectomy)
  • Severe comminution: Total patellectomy

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tension band wiring with cancellous screws. The surgical management of patellar fractures has evolved over the years from simple cerclage wiring to tension band wiring (TBW) which was further modified to increase its strength. Cancellous screws have also been used in the management of transverse patellar fractures, with high failure rates compared to modified tension band wiring.

 

Option C. Patellectomy. It is done in cases of comminuted fracture/irreducible or irreparable fracture or when cartilage too badly damaged. In a complete patellectomy, quadriceps muscles is attached to the patellar ligament to ensure function of the extensor apparatus Patellectomy is the last treatment of choice due to significant loss of extension.

 

Option D. Cylinder cast. If the fracture is not displaced & the extensor mechanism is intact, the fracture may be treated by means of immobilization, by placing the extremity in a cylinder cast for 4-6 weeks. The patient is allowed to bear weight in the cast.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a displaced transverse fracture of patella, tension band wiring by K-wires and stainless steel wire is the treatment option.

questions.text: A patient presents with tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum. Identify the lesion. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bankart’s lesion

 

BANKART’S LESION

 

  • In 1938, Bankart published his classic paper in which he recognized two types of acute dislocations.
  • In the first type, the humeral head is forced through the capsule, where it is the weakest, generally anteriorly and inferiorly in the interval between the lower border of the subscapularis and the long head of the triceps muscle.
  • In the second type, the humeral head is forced anteriorly out of the glenoid cavity and tears the fibrocartilaginous labrum from almost the entire anterior half of the rim of the glenoid cavity, and also the capsule and periosteum from the anterior surface of the neck of the scapula.
  • This traumatic detachment of the glenoid labrum has been called the Bankart lesion.
  • Bankart lesion is the most commonly observed pathological lesion in recurrent subluxation or dislocation of the shoulder.

 

 

  • This result in anterior instability of the shoulder joint due to the loss of the normal mechanisms, such as the block effect of the labrum, concavity compression mechanism of the rotator cuff, and function of the inferior glenohumeral ligament.
  • Lesions of the glenoid labrum are most commonly the result of traumatic anterior shoulder dislocation with the shoulder in external rotation and abduction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hill-Sachs lesion. A Hill-Sachs lesion is an osseous defect or "dent" of the postero-supero-lateral humeral head that occurs in association with anterior instability or dislocation of the glenohumeral joint. It is often associated with a Bankart lesion of the glenoid. This lesion is caused by an anterior shoulder dislocation which causes a humeral head impression fracture. The posterolateral aspect of the humeral head impacts on the anterior glenoid in the dislocated position, causing shoulder instability. If these lesions involve more than 20% of the glenoid, they can result in recurrent instability despite having an excellent soft-tissue repair. They are also called as impression fractures.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • A tear in the anteroinferior aspect of the glenoid capsule and labrum is called Bankart’s lesion, which is caused due to traumatic anterior dislocation of the shoulder.

choices.text: Lunate at place while others dislocate
Lunate is displaced while other are at place
Lunate is displaced volarly while carpus dislocate dorsally

questions.text: Perilunate dislocation is defined as:(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lunate at place while others dislocate

 

WRIST DISLOCATION

 

 

A. Normal; B. Lunate dislocation; C. Perilunate dislocation; D. Normal

 

1. Lunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate dislocates anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position

 

 

A. Pie sign; B. Spilled tea pot sign

 

2. Perilunate dislocation

 

  • Lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally.
  • Perilunate dislocation is more common
  • Most common type: Trans-scaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation
  • Complications: AVN, osteoarthritis and median nerve injury
  • Median nerve is most commonly injured nerve
  • The most commonly used method for closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Lunate is displaced while other are at place. This occurs in lunate dislocation.

 

Option C. Capitate dislocates volarly. This is rarely seen. There is dislocation of distal end of capitate at the capitate-metacarpal joint. It involves disruption of the joint and the intercarpal ligaments of the distal carpal row and minimally displaced fracture of trapezoid. This type of injury can be missed during the evaluation.

 

 

Educational objective:

 

Perilunate dislocation is defined as the dislocation of all carpal bones except for the lunate, which remains at its place.

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis based on this X-ray?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patella fracture

 

  • The given image shows a comminuted patellar fracture with the fracture lines visible and moderate joint effusion.

 

 

PATELLA FRACTURE

 

  • Patellar fractures are usually caused by direct trauma, such as a fall from standing height onto the flexed knee or a dashboard impact from a motor vehicle collision.
  • These fractures can also be caused by rapid contracture of the quadriceps with a flexed knee that can lead to loss of the extensor mechanism.
  • Patella fractures account for 1% of all skeletal injuries and 6-9% are open fractures.
  • Male to female ratio is 2:1 and most fractures occur in 20-50 year olds.
  • On inspection, a palpable patellar defect, significant hemarthrosis, and lacerations, abrasions in setting of open fractures are found.
  • The patient has an inability to perform straight leg raise.
  • The extensor mechanism and retinaculum are disrupted.
  • Lateral view radiograph is the best view for transverse fractures. It is obtained in 30⁰ knee flexion.

 

Lateral view showing effusion in the knee

 

  • Axial view is the best view for vertical fractures.

 

 

  • An important differential diagnosis of patellar fracture is bipartite patella which can be mistaken as patella fracture. It shows smooth and regular borders on the radiograph; can be bilateral in 50% cases, and is characteristically seen in superolateral position.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibial Condyle fracture: Tibial Plateau fractures are periarticular injuries of the proximal tibia frequently associated with soft tissue injury. Incidence is 1-2% of all fractures. It can be caused in males in age group of 40s due to high energy trauma, and in females of age group of 70s due to low energy falls. Incidence of lateral plateau fracture is 70-80% (due to valgus load), bicondylar is 10-30% (due to axial load), and of medial plateau is 10-20% (due to varus load). In a high energy trauma, there is fracture-dislocation of the medial plateau with soft tissue injuries (meniscus and ACL tear, common peroneal nerve injury). Low energy traumas cause lateral plateau fractures. AP, lateral and oblique radiograph views are helpful; oblique view helps in determining amount of depression. AP view shows depressed articular surface and abnormal joint alignment. Lateral view shows posteromedial fracture lines and abnormal tibial slope.

 


AP and Lateral view showing tibial condyle/plateau fracture

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic inflammatory autoimmune disease of unknown etiology that affects approximately 1% of the world population, with approximately 50% of adults being unable to work within 10 years of disease onset. The disease involves synovial joints and leads to progressive joint destruction. The knee joint is commonly involved in RA. Severe destruction of the articular cartilage and menisci is a characteristic feature of RA. Bone marrow edema and bone erosion can both also be found, but are less characteristic.

 

 

Option D. Hemarthrosis of Knee Joint: Hemarthrosis is bleeding into a joint cavity. It is best diagnosed with arthrocentesis and synovial fluid analysis. Traumatic injury is the most common cause of hemarthrosis. Non-traumatic hemarthrosis can be caused by bleeding disorders that are either hereditary or acquired. Hereditary bleeding disorders include hemophilia and inherited coagulation factor deficiency disorders. Examples of acquired bleeding disorders include advanced liver or renal disease, vitamin K deficiency, disseminated intravascular coagulation, or anticoagulation medication use. Post-operative recurrent hemarthrosis is frequently associated with total knee arthroplasty. The preferred initial imaging modality is plain film radiology of the involved joint and surrounding bones. If a fracture is not seen but strongly suspected, further evaluation with a CT scan is warranted. MRI may be able to diagnose ligamentous or other soft tissue injuries as the cause of hemarthrosis. Ultrasound (US) can help identify and characterize intra-articular fluid collections. The synovial fluid from a hemarthrosis may appear red, pink, or brown depending on the cause of bleeding. Aspiration of the joint and subsequent analysis can differentiate simple effusion, hemarthrosis, lipohemarthrosis, and septic arthritis.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows the comminuted fracture of the patella.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male having pain and deformity of the tibia as shown in X-ray. He had history of trauma 2 years back. What is the most probable diagnosis?(NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chronic osteomyelitis

 

CHRONIC OSTEOMYELITIS

 

  • Usually a sequela of inadequately treated acute osteomyelitis.
  • Causative organism: staphylococcus aureus
  • Presenting Complaints:
    • A chronic discharging sinus is the commonest presenting symptom.
    • The onset of sinus may be traced back to an episode of acute osteomyelitis during childhood.
    • Often sinuses heal for short periods, only to reappear with each acute exacerbation.
    • Discharge: Quality of discharge varies from seropurulent to thick pus.
    • There may be a history of extrusion of small bone fragments from the sinus.
    • Pain: Pain is usually minimal but may become aggravated during acute exacerbations.
    • Generalized symptoms of infection such as fever etc., are present only during acute exacerbations.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Thickening and irregularity of the cortices
    • Patchy sclerosis
    • Bone cavity: This is seen as an area of rarefaction surrounded by sclerosis.
    • Sequestrum: It is a piece of dead bone, surrounded by infected granulation tissue. It is pathognomic of chronic osteomyelitis. This appears denser than the surrounding normal bone because the decalcification which occurs in normal bone, does not occur in dead bone. Granulation tissue surrounding the sequestrum gives rise to a radiolucent zone around it. A sequestrum may be visible in soft tissues. It acts as nidus of infection and is the most common cause of non-healing sinus in chronic osteomyelitis. A chronic persistent neutrophilic discharge may be seen.
    • Involucrum is the dense sclerotic bone overlying a sequestrum formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. It is usually obvious by the end of 2nd week.
    • If infection persists, pus and tiny sequestrated spicules of bone may continue to discharge from the perforations called cloacae.

 

 

  • Rim sign is seen on MRI.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of chronic osteomyelitis is primarily surgical.
    • Paprika sign is the appearance of the live bone after removal of sequestrum.
       

 

  • Antibiotics are useful only during acute exacerbations and during postoperative period.
  • Various surgical options are:
    • Sequestrectomy
    • Saucerisation
    • Curettage
    • Excision of an infected bone
    • Amputation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s sarcoma. Ewing sarcoma is the fourth most common primary malignancy of bone, but it is the second most common (after osteosarcoma) in patients younger than 30 years of age and the most common in patients younger than 10 years of age. Its maximum incidence is seen in 2nd decade of life. Pain is an almost universal complaint of patients. In addition to pain, patients also may have fever, erythema, and swelling suggesting osteomyelitis. Laboratory studies may reveal increased WBC count, an elevated ESR, and an elevated CRP. Classically, Ewing sarcoma appears radiographically as a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of a long bone with an “onion skin” periosteal reaction. Ewing sarcoma more often originates in the metaphysis of a long bone, but frequently extends for a considerable distance into the diaphysis. Lung is the most common site of metastases. The worst prognostic factor is the presence of distant metastases. Even with aggressive treatment, patients with metastases have only a 20% chance of long-term survival. The treatment include neoadjuvant or adjuvant chemotherapy, or both, to treat distant metastases. Chemotherapy is much more effective and include vincristine, actinomycin D, cyclophosphamide, bleomycin, adriamycin, ifosfamide and etoposide.

 

  • ABCD: Actinomycin D / Bleomycin / Cyclophosphamide / Doxorubicin
  • Best results are achieved by Preoperative chemotherapy; then wide excision (or amputation) if tumor is in favorable site and further chemotherapy for 1 year. Subsequently Radiotherapy may be given.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Stress fracture of tibia. A tibial shaft stress fracture is an overuse injury where normal or abnormal bone is subjected to repetitive stress, resulting in microfractures. It is commonly seen in runners. There is linear microfracture in trabecular bone from repetitive loading. The patient have pain directly over the fracture which initially worsen after running. Diagnosis can often be made on radiographs alone but MRI studies should be obtained in patients with normal radiographs with a high degree of suspicion for stress fracture. Lateral x-ray shows dreaded black line anteriorly, endosteal thickening, periosteal reaction with cortical thickening. Treatment is activity restriction with protected weight-bearing in most cases. Surgical intramedullary nailing is recommended in the presence of an anterior tibia tension-sided stress fracture ("dreaded black line").

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiological image shown in the question and the clinical symptoms described are suggestive of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was operated for a tumour in the lower end of femur. The gross specimen of the resected tumour is shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INCET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The matrix forming the tumor is the cause of calcification.
  • It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone behind multiple myeloma.
  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • It occurs more frequently in males than in females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Characteristic histological feature is malignant cells with osteoid formation. This osteoid matrix presents as calcification.
  • Osteosarcoma is the most common radiation-induced sarcoma.
  • Clinical features:
    • Almost all patients report progressive pain. Night pain may be an important clue to the true diagnosis, seen in 25% of patients
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.

 

 

Codman’s triangle

 

  • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.

 

 

  • MRI is the best test to measure the extent of the tumor within the bone and in the soft tissue and to determine the relationship of the tumor to nearby anatomical structures.
  • A bone scan should be obtained to look for skeletal metastases, and radiographs and CT scans of the chest should be done to search for pulmonary metastases; the lungs are the most common sites of metastases.
  • CT scan may be helpful in differentiating osteosarcoma from myositis ossificans or an osteochondroma. The ossification in myositis ossificans is more mature at the periphery of the lesion, whereas the center of osteosarcoma is more heavily ossified.
  • Treatment:
    • It is highly radio-resistant tumor and ideally, treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. GCT. They typically occur in patients 20-40 years old, and there is a slight female predominance. The most common location for this tumor is the distal femur, followed closely by the proximal tibia. Tumor of lower end radius is GCT till proved otherwise. GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation. Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients. Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT. Radiographic findings often are diagnostic. The lesions are eccentrically located in the epiphyses of long bones and usually about the subchondral bone with soap bubble appearance. Microscopically, giant cell tumors are composed of many multinucleated giant cells (typically 40-60 nuclei per cell) in a sea of mononuclear stromal cells (malignant cells). Curettage and stripping of the cavity is the treatment of choice.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows a cut section of osteosarcoma of the femur.
  • The destructive tumor arises from the metaphysis, with extensive involvement of the marrow cavity and extension into soft tissue.

choices.text: Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip.
Vascular injury is more common in anterior hip dislocation.
Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior.
In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation.

questions.text: Mark incorrect option: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nerve injury more common in anterior dislocation of hip.

 

 

 

  • “Nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation of hip” – this statement is incorrect. 
  • In posterior hip dislocations, the sciatic nerve is at significant risk of injury. This is the most common nerve injury associated with hip dislocations.
  • In anterior hip dislocations, the femoral nerve or obturator nerve can be injured, but these are generally less common than sciatic nerve injury in posterior dislocations.
  • Therefore, stating nerve injury is more common in anterior dislocation is false as it is more common in posterior dislocations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vascular injury more common in anterior hip dislocation. This statement is correct. This is so because the femoral vessels are in close proximity to the hip joint anteriorly, so there are more chances of vascular injury to occur from anterior hip dislocation. Major vascular injuries are rare in both anterior and posterior dislocations. 

 

Option C. Posterior dislocation of hip is more common than anterior. This statement is correct. The incidence of posterior dislocation of hip is around 90%. This is because of the greater strength of anterior ligaments than the posterior ones. 

 

Option D. In posterior hip dislocation, attitude of limb is adduction, flexion and internal rotation. This statement is true. The position of the limb when a patient presents with posterior hip dislocation is of Flexion, Adduction and Internal Rotation i.e., FADIR while in anterior dislocation, it is FABER i.e., Flexion, Abduction and External Rotation. 

 

 

FADIR in posterior hip dislocation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In anterior dislocation of hip, vascular injuries are more common whereas in posterior dislocation, nerve injury (particularly sciatic nerve) is more common.

questions.text: A patient came to the emergency department with a history of being involved in a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft. The patient's condition was promptly stabilized. However, after a period of 12 hours, the individual experienced a sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and the appearance of small reddish-purple skin rashes (petechiae) over the chest and underarm areas. What potential diagnosis could explain these symptoms? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fat embolism

 

  • The probable diagnosis derived from the given clinical scenario can be fat embolism.
  • Fat embolism although should be diagnosed with trauma to long bone, usually Femur and clinical presentation of pulmonary involvement, CNS depression and skin involvement (Petechiae).

 

FAT EMBOLISM SYNDROME

 

  • Fat embolism refers to the presence of fat globules in vital organs and peripheral circulation after fracture of a long bone or other major trauma.
  • Fat embolism syndrome reflects a serious systemic manifestation as a consequence to these emboli.
  • Fat embolism is more commonly seen in patients with multiple fractures and in fractures involving lower limbs especially femur.
  • Fat originates from the site of trauma, particularly from the injured marrow. Fat globules > 10 mm are considered significant.
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Early warning signs are a slight rise in temperature and pulse rate (tachycardia).
    • The classical triad of fat embolism syndrome is:
      1. Respiratory symptoms: Dyspnea or tachypnea
      2. Neurological symptoms: Confusion or disorientation
      3. Petechial rash: In axilla, neck, periumbilical area, conjunctiva of lower lid, front and back of chest, shoulder
  • Diagnostic Criterion for Fat Embolism:

 

 

  • 1 major + 4 minor = Fat embolism

 

  • Prevention:
    • Fracture stabilization
    • Removing fat emboli from circulation by:
      • Lipolytic agents as heparin (increase serum lipase activity)
      • Hypertonic glucose (decrease FFA production)
  • Offset its effect by:
    • Dextran (expand plasma volume, reduces RBC aggregation and platelet adherence)
    • Aprotinin (protease inhibitor) – decreases platelet aggregation and serotonin release
    • Alcohol has vasodilator and lipolytic effect.
  • Treatment:
    • The aim of treatment is maintaining adequate oxygen level in the blood. If necessary, by using intermittent positive pressure ventilation. Oxygen is the only therapeutic tool of proven use.
    • It should be administered in sufficient amount to maintain arterial PO2 > 80 mm Hg. O2 toxicity (pneumonitis) is avoided by using O2 conc. below 40%.
    • Steroids are given to Avoid Pneumonitis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Head injury. Based on the mechanism, head trauma is classified as blunt (the most common mechanism), penetrating (most fatal), and blast. Most severe TBIs result from motor vehicle collisions and falls. A good history concerning the mechanism of injury is important. GCS is used to describe the level of consciousness. A patient with mild head injury may present with swelling from a bump or a bruise, small, superficial cut in the scalp, headache, sensitivity to noise and light, irritability, confusion, dizziness, balance problems, nausea, problems with memory and/or concentration, blurred vision, tinnitus. Moderate to severe head injury symptoms may include any of the above plus loss of consciousness, severe headache that does not go away, repeated nausea and vomiting, loss of short-term memory, such as difficulty remembering the events that led right up to and through the traumatic event, slurred speech, difficulty with walking, weakness in one side or area of the body, sweating, pale skin, seizures, blood or clear fluid draining from the ears or nose, one pupil  is dilated, or looks larger, than the other eye and doesn't constrict, or get smaller, when exposed to light , deep cut or laceration in the scalp, open wound in the head, foreign object penetrating the head, coma.

 

Option C. Blunt trauma to chest. Chest trauma remains a serious problem in high-speed vehicle accidents. Thoracic trauma occurs in approximately 60% patients and has a mortality of 20-25%. The mortality rate in blunt chest trauma may be due to pulmonary and non-pulmonary complications. In the primary survey of chest trauma patients, 6 life-threatening conditions (airway obstruction, tension pneumothorax, open pneumothorax, massive hemothorax, flail chest, pericardial tamponade) should be immediately investigated and treated. Signs and symptoms of thoracic trauma include cyanosis of fingers, lips or face, dyspnea, tachypnea or bradypnea, contusion, laceration, perforations, distension, hemoptysis, signs of shock (hypoperfusion), tracheal deviation, paradoxical movement of the chest wall, distended jugular veins, decreased or absent breathing sounds, pain, failure of chest expansion in normal inspiration. Respiratory distress is a serious problem and the patients may breathe with nasal flaring, using accessory muscles, intercostal and subcostal retractions, and tachypnea. The patient's lungs may not be equally involved in breathing. Paradoxical respiration can be observed and immediate diagnosis of flail chest can be made.

 

Option D. Hemorrhagic shock. Shock refers to the inadequate perfusion of tissues due to the imbalance between the oxygen demand of tissues and the body’s ability to supply it. Blunt or penetrating trauma is the most common cause, followed by upper and lower gastrointestinal sources. Bleeding may be either external or internal. It occurs due to the depletion of intravascular volume through blood loss to the point of being unable to match the tissues demand for oxygen. As a result, mitochondria are unable to sustain aerobic metabolism for the production of oxygen and switch to the less efficient anaerobic metabolism to meet the cellular demand for adenosine triphosphate which leads to pyruvate production and conversion to lactic acid to maintain some degree of cellular respiration. The body compensates by increasing heart rate and contractility, followed by baroreceptor activation resulting in sympathetic nervous system activation and peripheral vasoconstriction. Signs and symptoms include blue lips and finger nails, low or no urine output, excessive sweating, shallow breathing, dizziness or loss of consciousness, confusion, chest pain, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, weak pulse.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • History of a road traffic accident, resulting in a fracture of the femur shaft with appearance of symptoms of sudden onset of difficulty breathing, confusion, and small reddish-purple skin rashes over the chest and underarm areas after a period of 12 hours all indicates fat embolism which needs immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented with chronic low back pain and early morning stiffness since last 2 years, which is also associated with bilateral heel pain. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ankylosing spondylitis

 

ANKYLOSING SPONDYLITIS

 

  • Also known as Marie-Strumpell or Bechterew’s disease.
  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • It is a chronic inflammatory disease affecting the spine and sacroiliac joints.
  • It also have a variable involvement of root joints (shoulder and hip) and peripheral joints.
  • The involvement is an enthesopathy.
  • HLA B27 is positive in 90% patients.
  • Sacroiliitis is the earliest manifestation with features of both enthesitis and synovitis.
  • Joints Involved:
    • Primarily affects axial skeleton.
    • The disease usually begins in the sacroiliac joints and usually extends upwards to involve the lumbar, thoracic, and often cervical spine.
    • Hip joint is the most commonly affected peripheral joint.
    • Rarely, knee and ankle are also involved.
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • It is most commonly seen in young males aged 15-25 years.
    • Most common symptom is dull backache, insidious in onset, felt deep in lower lumbar or gluteal region, associated with low back morning stiffness of up to few hour duration that improves with activity and returns following period of inactivity.
    • Question mark (?) posture is due to hyperkyphosis of thoracic spine and loss of lumbar lordosis.
    • Cervical spine involvement is usually late and show forward stooping and loss of extension and rotation.
    • Most serious complication of spinal disease is spinal fracture with even minor trauma.
    • Anterior uveitis: Most common (30%) extra-articular manifestation.
    • Cataract and secondary glaucoma are common sequela.
    • Up to 60% of patients have inflammation of colon or ileum (mostly asymptomatic, only 5-10% develop IBD), 3rd degree heart block, cardiac dysfunction (Aortic incompetence), restrictive lung disease. IgA nephropathy, prostatitis and retroperitoneal fibrosis are other manifestations and may shorten life span.
       
  • Diagnostic criteria – Modified New York Criterion:
    • Essential criteria is definite radiographic sacroiliitis
    • Supporting criteria: one of these 3
      • Inflammatory back pain if 4/5 are present 
        1. Pain > 3 months
        2. < 40 years of age
        3. Insidious onset
        4. Improves with exercise
        5. Present at night
           
      • Limited chest expansion
      • Limited lumbar spine motion in both sagittal and frontal plane (schober test/modified schober test)
         
  • Spine Radiograph Findings:
    • Haziness of sacroiliac (SI) joint margins is the earliest change.

 

 

Sacroiliitis

  • Later on, SI joint show irregular subchondral erosions, sclerotic articular margins, joint space widening and eventually bony ankylosis.
  • Calcification of supraspinous and interspinous ligaments (Dagger sign) and that of sacroiliac and sacro-tuberous ligament.

 

 

Dagger sign (ossification along supraspinous & interspinous ligaments)

  • Enthesopathy: Calcification at the attachment of muscles, tendons and ligaments.
  • Trolley/tram track sign: Three linear radiopaque lines due to ligament calcification.
  • Squaring of vertebra, loss of lumbar lordosis and syndesmophytes are seen. Bamboo spine appearance is due to syndesmophytes.

 

 

A. Trolley track sign (ossification along supraspinous ligaments and facet joints; B. Bamboo spine

 

  • MRI is the most sensitive examination for sacroiliitis.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. TB spine. In pott’s spine, the commonest & usually the 1st symptom is back pain, which is usually minimal. Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for Anterior elements is more significant as disease is anteriorly involving the vertebral body (paradiscal). Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When bending forward, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine are in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier). The Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm. There is reduction of intervertebral disk space and osteoporosis of two adjacent vertebrae, sometimes with fuzziness of the endplates. Paraspinal abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.

 

 

Option C. Mechanical back pain. Mechanical back strain is a subtype of back pain where the etiology is the spine, intervertebral discs, or the surrounding soft tissues. Lower back is usually affected the most. More than 80% of people will suffer from low back pain during their lifetime. There is a higher prevalence among women and people ages 40-80 years. Acute mechanical back strains may be triggered by physical or non-physical activity, with lifting being the most commonly recalled event. The patient complaints of axial lumbosacral pain and/or radicular pain into the lower extremity. Low back pain does not necessarily correlate with imaging findings. Plain radiograph is suitable to assess bony abnormalities or fractures.

 

Option D. Prolapsed intervertebral disc. The commonest site of disc prolapse is lumbar spine. In more than 95% of cases lumbar disc herniation are localized at L4-L5 (50% cases) and L5-S1 (45% cases). The next commonest site of intervertebral disc prolapse is lower cervical spine (C5-C6). Lumbar disc is dehydrated hence more prone. Small herniation of nucleus pulposus produce Schmorl’s nodules. Degenerated disc is extruded posteriorly in three patterns: Central, Paracentral (annulus bulges to one side of posterior longitudinal ligament – most common type and produced unilateral radicular symptoms), and Far lateral disc herniation (bulge is within or just lateral to neural foramina).

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The described symptoms of chronic low back pain, early morning stiffness, and bilateral heel pain are suggestive of ankylosing spondylitis which involves the enthesis of the body.

questions.text: A patient presents in the OPD complaining of unable to evert the ankle. The following deformity is seen. Which of the following gait is present?(INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stepping gait

 

  • The image shown in the question is of high-stepping gait, where the foot drops due to common peroneal nerve injury and while walking, the foot slaps on the ground.

 

COMMON PERONEAL NERVE INJURY

 

  • The common peroneal nerve is one of the two major branches of the sciatic nerve.
  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates the lateral compartment of the leg, and the deep peroneal nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the leg and the dorsum of the foot.
  • These two nerves are essential in the eversion of the foot and dorsiflexion of the foot, respectively.
  • The innervation of the superficial peroneal nerve are:
    • Motor:
      • Peroneus longus
      • Peroneus brevis
    • Sensory: Anterolateral leg
  • Deep peroneal nerve innervation are:
    • Motor:
      • Tibialis anterior
      • Extensor hallucis longus
      • Extensor digitorum longus
      • Peroneus tertius
    • Sensory: First dorsal webspace
  • The nerve is most vulnerable to injury as it passes around the fibular neck.
  • The most common presentation of a common peroneal nerve injury is a weakness of ankle dorsiflexion and the classic resultant foot drop while ambulating. 
  • Foot drop can develop acutely or over days to weeks, depending on the etiology. It can also be complete or partial in severity.
  • There may also be accompanying numbness or paresthesia present along the lateral leg, dorsal foot, and/or the first toe webspace.
  • Pain may also be present in traumatic cases but is not always present.
  • A patient with weakened or paralyzed dorsiflexors may ambulate with a high steppage gait to prevent dragging of toes on the ground.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Waddling gait. Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, like in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture of the hip joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients have difficulty in standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase. This waddling gait pattern can also be caused when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck. 

 

 

Option C. Circumduction gait. Also called as Hemiplegic gait, circumduction gait is most commonly seen in stroke. The patient stands with unilateral weakness on the affected side with arm flexed, adducted and internally rotated. Leg on the same side is in extension with plantar flexion of the foot and toes. While walking, the patient hold their arm to one side and drags the affected leg in semi-circle or circumduction due to weakness of the distal muscles (foot drop) and extensor hypertonia in the lower limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is the high stepping gait, seen in the common peroneal nerve injury. This gait is present due to foot drop or weakness of the foot dorsiflexors.

questions.text: Patient had difficulty in walking upstairs. When he was made to bear weight on right lower limb, the left-sided pelvis dropped down, but when he was standing on the left lower limb, the right-sided pelvis moved up. Which of the following is the likely lesion? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Right superior gluteal nerve palsy

 

WADDLING (GLUTEAL OR TRENDELENBURG) GAIT

 

  • This gait is characteristic of the gluteal muscle weakness that is seen in the progressive muscular dystrophies, but it occurs as well in chronic forms of spinal muscular atrophy, in certain inflammatory myopathies, lumbosacral nerve root compression, and with congenital dislocation of the hips.
  • It can also occur in neurogenic conditions in which the superior gluteal nerve is involved.
  • In normal walking, as weight is placed alternately on each leg, the hip is fixated by the gluteal muscles, particularly the gluteus medius, allowing for a slight rise of the opposite hip and tilt of the trunk to the weight-bearing side.
  • With weakness of the glutei, however, there is a failure to stabilize the weight-bearing hip, causing it to bulge outward and the opposite side of the pelvis to drop, with inclination of the trunk to that side.
  • The alternation in lateral trunk movements results in the roll or waddle.
  • With unilateral gluteal weakness, often the result of damage to the first sacral nerve root, tilting and dropping of the pelvis (“pelvic ptosis”) is apparent on only one side as the patient overlifts the leg when walking.
  • In several of the muscular dystrophies, an accentuation of lumbar lordosis is often seen.
  • Also, childhood cases may be complicated by muscular contractures, leading to an equinovarus position of the foot, so that the waddle is combined with walking on the toes (“toe walking”).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left superior gluteal nerve palsy. When the patient is standing on one leg, the opposite pelvis should be lifted upwards by abduction of the ipsilateral hip joint, in a normal patient. When the abductors are weak due to superior gluteal nerve paresis, the pelvis will sag, called positive Trendelenburg sign. In a patient with a positive Trendelenburg sign, the pelvis sags toward the normal unsupported side, which is the swing leg. When the left superior gluteal nerve is affected, on standing on the left lower limb, the right side pelvis will drop and when the patient stands on the right leg, the left side pelvis will be lifted up.

 

Option C. Right inferior gluteal nerve palsy. The inferior gluteal nerve supplies the gluteus maximus muscle. It is therefore, responsible for extending the trunk from a forward bending position and extending the hip from sitting-to-standing or during stair-climbing or rising from a squatted position. The nerve does not confer any sensation. Injury to this nerve is most commonly iatrogenic in origin and is the most at risk nerve during total hip arthroplasty via a posterior approach. Injury typically leads to an altered gait pattern known as gluteus maximus ‘lurch’. The sequelae of nerve injury are denervation of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle. The lurching gait results from the weakening or absence of an ipsilateral hip extension. Clinically, patients may also report wasting of the ipsilateral gluteus maximus muscle and loss of the defined shape to the affected buttock. In a normal gait cycle, the gluteus maximus begin to contract at the moment of the ipsilateral heel-strike to initiate ipsilateral hip extension. In inferior gluteal nerve injury, the trunk will extend when the heel strikes on the ground on the affected side to compensate for weak/absent hip extension. This backward trunk lurch is present in the whole stance phase of the gait cycle and locks the hip in extension. In some cases, the hamstrings muscle compensates to an extent. Therefore, in the right inferior gluteal nerve palsy, the right side hip will not extend during the initial heel strike and the trunk will lean backwards/extend.

 

Option D. Left inferior gluteal nerve palsy. In the injury of left sided gluteal nerve, the left hip will not extend during the initial heel strike, leading to backward lurch or extension of the trunk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • On standing on the right lower limb, the left side pelvis drops and while standing on the left leg, the right side pelvis lifted up. This is indicative of right superior gluteal nerve palsy. This sign is called Trendelenburg Sign.

choices.text: Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm
Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury
Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required
Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

questions.text: A patient with open wound, with fracture of both bones of right lower limb came to the emergency. The doctor labelled the injury as type 3B according to Gustilo-Anderson Classification. Which of the following would represent the injury? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Open wound > 10 cm, with extensive injury requiring soft tissue coverage

 

GUSTILO AND ANDERSON CLASSIFICATION FOR OPEN FRACTURE

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Open wound with fracture, with wound <1 cm. This is the description of Type I of open fracture where the wound is clean and of <1cm length.  

 

Option B. Open wound with fracture, 1 to 10 cm wound size, but mild soft tissue injury. This is the description of Type II of open fracture where the wound length is >1cm with mild soft tissue damage or skin flap or avulsion.

 

Option C. Open wound >10 cm, though soft tissue coverage not required. This is the description of Type IIIA of the open fracture where there is an adequate periosteal coverage present.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type IIIB of the open fracture is the open wound with significant periosteal stripping.
  • It requires secondary bone coverage and procedures like skin grafting or flap.

questions.text: Identify the sign and the tendon ruptured in the image given below: (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Proximal biceps tendon rupture

 

PROXIMAL BICEPS TENDON RUPTURE

 

  • The biceps brachii muscle has two heads, one originating from the coracoid process (short head) and the other from the supraglenoid tubercle of the scapula and superior labrum (long head).
  • The distal biceps tendon attaches to the bicipital tuberosity of the radius.
  • The biceps tendon is a strong supinator of the forearm and serves as a weak elbow flexor.
  • The long head (proximal biceps tendon) contributes to the stability of the glenohumeral joint. The majority of biceps rupture involves the long head.
  • Etiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is generally not due to a unique mechanism of injury but is highly correlated with rotator cuff disease.
    • Risk factors include age, smoking, obesity, use of corticosteroids, and overuse.
    • Rare causes include the use of quinolones, diabetes, lupus, and chronic kidney disease.
       
  • Epidemiology:
    • Proximal biceps rupture is commonly seen in older patients, and its exact incidence is unknown, but it is more common than distal biceps rupture in older patients.
       
  • Pathophysiology
    • The proximal tendon rupture, in most cases, occurs at the tendon-labral junction or the bony attachment.
       
  • Clinical features:
    • Patients may complain of sudden sharp pain in the elbow or shoulder, depending on the site of the rupture.
    • Usually, there is a history of sudden eccentric force to a flexed elbow. They may feel an audible "pop" in the affected arm at the time of the injury.
    • Pain can persist for weeks to months.
    • Pain may diminish if the tendon is completely torn.
    • Patients usually complain of bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly, known as "Popeye deformity." In obese individuals, it is generally hard to appreciate this popeye deformity.

 

  • Proximal biceps rupture does not result in any long-term change in the elbow or shoulder strength.
  • It is important to check for atrophy of the shoulder girdle muscle and shoulder impingement because proximal biceps tendon disorders are usually associated with rotator cuff pathology.
     
  • Evaluation:
    • Diagnosis is often clinically made, while imaging is helpful when the diagnosis is unclear or partial rupture is considered.
    • Three criteria are described for diagnosis:
      1. History of a single traumatic event. The patient will report a sudden, painful pop while the elbow is eccentrically loaded from flexion to extension. e.g., while doing a biceps curl.
      2. Grossly palpable and visible signs of retraction of the biceps muscle belly (reverse popeye deformity).
      3. Weakness of elbow flexion and supination of the forearm in cases of distal biceps rupture.
         
  • Treatment:
    • Non-surgical treatment is usually sufficient for proximal tendon rupture, as it is more common in elderly patients. However, residual cosmetic deformity and some intermittent biceps muscle cramping may persist.
    • Younger patients and female patients who are unwilling to accept cosmetic deformities and athletic patients with frequent cramping may opt for surgical intervention in the form of biceps tenodesis.
    • The presence of associated rotator cuff pathology can also influence surgical management.
    • Subpectoral tenodesis is the preferred approach for biceps tenodesis, where the tendon is attached to the bone in the bicipital groove. Sometimes this procedure is done concurrently with arthroscopic rotator cuff pathology treatment. Implants like interference screws and bio-absorbable suture anchors can be placed either through the open or arthroscopic approach to secure the tendon in the subpectoral space.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Distal biceps tendon rupture. The distal biceps tendon inserts onto the ulnar aspect of the bicipital tuberosity (also called radial tuberosity). The likely pathophysiological mechanism predisposing the distal biceps to rupture is a compromised zone of hypovascularity due to watershed zone of arterial blood supply and reduced distance between the upper parts of radius and the ulna during pronation. An aching sensation in the anterior elbow is seen in 10% of the patients. Majority of the patients with a full thickness distal biceps rupture reports a painful “pop” sensation. Anterior elbow pain, anterior arm and elbow swelling and weakness of elbow flexion and forearm supination are commonly reported symptoms. Activities such as operating a manual screw driver or opening jars are difficult to perform by involved arm. In a torn distal biceps, there would be anterior ecchymosis, swelling and a prominent biceps bulge at the anterior mid-arm level (Popeye the sailor sign).

 

 

Option C. Triceps tendon rupture. Triceps Ruptures are rare injuries to the elbow extensor mechanism that most commonly occurs as a result of a sudden forceful elbow contraction in weightlifters or older males with underlying systemic illness. Patients tend to be men who practice sports and are from 30 to 50 years of age. The triceps lesions are characterised by pain or tenderness and a palpable defect in the tendon, seen proximal to the olecranon. The patient describes an unexpected “pop” or giving way, with subsequent pain and weakness in the extremity. A complete triceps rupture can be expected when the patient is unable to extend his arm against gravity. A palpable defect is not always present, but sometimes can be found in the posterior arm. Swelling and echymosis are other nonspecific findings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The deformity shown in the given image in the question is seen in proximal biceps tendon rupture and is called Popeye deformity.

questions.text: Earliest sign of compartment syndrome of leg is:(AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pain on passive stretch

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes of compartment syndrome are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • In compartment syndrome the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments. Deep flexor muscles are involved particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tingling or numbness. Paresthesia, tingling or numbness occur in the late stages.

 

Option D. Pulselessness. It is also the late feature. Presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first sign of compartment syndrome is the pain and resistance to the passive stretch of the distal-most joint of the extremity.

questions.text: A 30-year-man presents with swelling over knee joint. Biopsy reveals mononuclear and giant cells. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteoclastoma

 

  • Lesion with giant cells and mononuclear cells in skeletally mature patient, GCT is the best answer.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • There is a slight female predominance.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The nuclei of the mononuclear cells are identical to the nuclei of giant cells – a feature that helps to distinguish giant cell tumor from other tumors that may contain giant cells.
       
  • GCT has egg shell crackling on palpation.
  • Although these tumors typically are benign, pulmonary metastases occur in approximately 3% of patients.
  • Malignant giant cell tumors represent less than 5% of total GCT.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling.
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10-15% of cases.
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
       
  • Radiological Features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region with distinct margins, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance, without any calcifications & reactive sclerosis
       
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chondrosarcoma. It occurs over a broad age range, with peaks between 40 and 60 years for primary chondrosarcoma and between 25 and 45 years for secondary chondrosarcoma. Most common in Proximal location like pelvis (most common site), proximal femur, and proximal humerus. Most common malignant tumor of bone in hand (although rarely occur). Secondary chondrosarcomas arise at the site of a pre-existing benign cartilage lesion like in case of multiple enchondromas and multiple hereditary exostoses. Chondrosarcoma can produce hyperglycemia in 85% cases. Metastasis from Chondrosarcoma most commonly goes to lungs (hematogenous). The radiographic appearance is similar to enchondroma, it is a lesion arising in the medullary cavity with irregular matrix calcification. The pattern of Calcification is described as “Punctate”, “popcorn”, or “comma-shaped”. It has a more aggressive appearance with Bone destruction, cortical erosions, periosteal reaction, and rarely a soft-tissue mass. Treatment is by Wide local excision/Radical excision.

 

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma. Osteosarcoma is a radiation-induced sarcoma. It is characterized by the production of osteoid matrix by malignant cells. It is the second most common primary malignancy of bone after multiple myeloma. It is most commonly seen in the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus. All patients report progressive pain. Night pain is also reported in about 25% patients. Characteristic findings are Codman’s triangle and Sunburst periosteal reaction. It is the most radioresistant bone tumor and treated by chemotherapy followed by limb salvage surgery/amputation followed by chemotherapy.

 

 

Option D. Chondroblastoma. Chondroblastoma is a rare type of benign tumor that grows at the ends of the long bones, close to the joints. Most often, the tumors develop at the ends of the femur, tibia, or humerus. They typically occur in children and young adults, and are more common in males. Although chondroblastomas are not cancerous, they can continue to grow if left untreated. A growing tumor can destroy the surrounding bone, making it painful to move the nearby joint. The cause of chondroblastomas is not known. The tumors are thought to arise from the growth plates at the ends of the bones, near joints. Classic “chicken wire” calcification is seen. Epiphysis + calcification + upper end humerus = Chondroblastoma.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Mononuclear giant cells in the histological findings is diagnostic for osteoclastoma or giant cell tumor.

questions.text: Most common joint involved in septic arthritis is:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee

 

SEPTIC (PYOGENIC) ARTHRITIS

 

  • Refers to Infection of Joint.
  • Septic arthritis word is a misnomer as initially, there is only infection of joint and if not treated early then, Arthritis develops. Thus, all sepsis of joints do not cause arthritis, only inadequately treated ones do.
  • Etiology and pathology:
    • Hematogenous route of infection is most common in all age groups
    • Most common organism: Staphylococcus aureus.
       
  • Diagnosis:
    • X-rays are usually normal or may indicate soft tissue swelling.
    • MRI may show effusion, synovitis or cartilage destruction.
    • Aspiration of joint fluid helps to confirm the diagnosis by culture and also helps to differentiate from transient synovitis.
    • Order of investigations done: X-ray followed by MRI, then Aspiration.
    • Culture of the aspirate is the gold standard for diagnosis.
       
  • Septic arthritis with negative cultures: Diagnostic Criterion (Morrey and associates criterion) – 5 out of 6 must be present
    1. > 38.3°C temperature
    2. Swelling of suspected joint
    3. Pain in joint that increases with movement
    4. Systemic symptoms
    5. No other pathologic process
    6. Satisfactory response to antibiotics therapy
       
  • Clinical Presentation:
    • Absent movements of a joint after ruling out trauma in pediatric population is septic arthritis until proven otherwise.
    • Knee: Most commonly affected joint; position is flexion
    • Hip: Position is flexion, abduction and external rotation.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Arthrotomy (opening the joint capsule), surgical drainage (decompression), synovectomy and antibiotics (2 weeks IV and 4 weeks oral).
    • Non-operative treatment is not considered as cartilage destruction occurs very rapidly and can cause permanent joint destruction.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hip. Infections that can affect the hip are primarily either an infection of the bone i.e., osteomyelitis, or an infection of the joint i.e., septic arthritis. 

 

Option C. Shoulder. Infection of the shoulder joint is rare. It may occur after total shoulder replacement. The most common bacteria responsible for the infection are Staphylococcus aureus, Staphylococcus epidermidis, and Propionibacterium acnes.

 

Option D. Elbow. Elbow joint infection may occur due to infected or septic arthritis, septic joint, infection after elbow surgery or after elbow replacement, bursal infection, soft tissue infection or cellulitis. 

 

Educational objective:

 

The most common joint involved in septic arthritis is the knee joint, followed by the hip joint.

questions.text: The last symptoms to develop in compartment syndrome is: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pulselessness

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndrome, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.

  • Most commonly compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).

  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.

  • Clinical Features:

  • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.

  • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) – 1st sign.

  • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome. The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis. 

  • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.

  • Acute compartment syndrome presents with the following 5 Ps:

 

 

  • Paralysis and Pulselessness are considered late and ominous signs, indicating severe and irreversible tissue damage. 
  • Paralysis and pulselessness signifies that the condition has progressed significantly, indicating permanent injury.
  • Pulselessness generally represents a more critical and terminal stage of circulatory compromise.
  • It implies complete or near-complete cessation of blood flow, which is ultimately the most severe and final physiological sign of impending tissue death.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pain on passive stretch. Pain and resistance to the passive stretch is the first sign of the compartment syndrome. 

 

Option B. Paralysis. Paralysis occurs in the late stages of the syndrome due to involvement of the nerves. 

 

Option C. Pallor. Pallor appears in the late stages and indicates irreversible muscle and nerve ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The last sign/symptom to appear in a compartment syndrome is pulselessness, as it signifies the most advanced stage of vascular compromise. 

  • While paralysis is also very late, the absence of a pulse is a definitive sign of severe, critical ischemia.

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple swelling in hand & wrist. Finger X-ray is given. Identify: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple enchondromatosis

 

ENCHONDROMA

 

  • When chondromas arise in the medullary canal, they’re referred to as enchondroma.
  • Enchondroma is benign tumor of short tubular bones of the hand.
  • They are seen after age of skeletal maturity.
  • These are the centric, non-expansile or minimally expansile tumors with marginal sclerosis.
  • Medullary cavity, Metaphysical tumour

 

 

  • Most common tumour of bones of hand and feet
  •  5% premalignant
  • Multiple enchondromas is also known as Ollier’s syndrome. There are multiple enchondromas all over the body.
  • Multiple enchondromas + subcutaneous Hemangioma + Phlebolith (Calcified superficial veins) = Maffucci syndrome

 

 

Maffucci syndrome: A) Hemangiomas, B) Phleboliths and Enchondromas

 

  • Malignant transformation to chondrosarcoma may occur in < 2% solitary cases, 30% in ollier disease and 100% in maffucci’s syndrome.
  • Treatment: Extended Curettage + bone grafting

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Multiple brown tumor. It has been reported that 2-5% patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have brown tumor (osteitis fibrosa cystica). Bone brown tumor secondary to primary hyperparathyroidism (PHPT) is very rare, which is caused by massive secretion of PTH. First, a large amount of bone calcium is mobilized into blood, resulting in fibrous tissue hyperplasia in bone and leaky hemorrhage. Then, macrophage reactive hyperplasia resulted in phagocytosis of red blood cells and a large amount of hemosiderin is produced, thereby forming a brown nodule. The lesions are usually multiple, most commonly seen in ribs, clavicle, pelvis, long bones and mandibles while others are rare. The radiograph of brown tumor is often characterized by osteoporosis, thinning of cortical bone and multiple localized cystic bone destruction.

 

 

Option C. Multiple osteophytic growth. Osteophytes are cartilage-capped bony proliferations that most commonly develop at the margins of a synovial joint as a response to articular cartilage damage, as seen very commonly in degenerative joint disease. Central osteophytes can develop from cartilage lesions within a joint. They are considered a hallmark of osteoarthritis. Osteophytes may be confused with syndesmophytes and enthesophytes. Small osteophytes are sometimes referred to as osteophytic lipping.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image in the question shows multiple enchondromas in the hand.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented after a motor vehicle accident to the emergency. On examination, the right lower limb was longer than the left, abducted and externally rotated. What can be the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Anterior hip dislocation

 

ANTERIOR HIP DISLOCATION

 

  • Anterior dislocations occur with the hip externally rotated and abducted.
  • The degree of flexion at the time of injury determines the eventual position of the femoral head.
  • They are associated with lengthening.
  • Hip dislocations are most common in young adult males and are most often the result of motor vehicle accidents. 
  • The patients present with hip and leg in extension, abduction, and external rotation.

 

 

  • Radiological findings include loss of congruence of femoral head with acetabulum, disruption of shenton's line, femoral head appears larger than contralateral femoral head, and femoral head lies medial or inferior to acetabulum.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Femoral nerve injury: Femoral nerve damage can occur from an injury or prolonged compression. Typically, damage and dysfunction of the femoral nerve are associated with the leg weakness and sensation changes. Injury of the femoral is uncommon but may be injured by a stab, gunshot wounds, or a pelvic fracture. It can also be damaged during hip replacement, abdominal, and pelvic surgeries. The patient presents with poor flexion of the hip because of paralysis of the iliacus, psoas and sartorius muscles. There is an inability to extend the knee because of paralysis of the quadriceps femoris. There is sensory decline over the anterior and medial aspects of the thigh, medial side of the leg and foot up to the first metatarsophalangeal joint. It does not directly affect the position of the hip or the length appearance of the limb.

 

Option B. Femoral neck fracture: Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture. The junctional location makes the femoral neck prone to fracture. It is commonly seen in the elderly due to low energy falls, and in young patients who perform athletics or due to high-energy trauma. The patient complains of pain with a decreased range of motion of the hip. In non-displaced fractures, there may be no deformity. However, displaced fractures may present with a shortened and externally rotated lower limb. The leg appears shortened due to the upward movement of the distal fragment. The key feature is the inability to bear weight and immediate pain.

 

 

Option C. Posterior hip dislocation: It is the Most common hip dislocation (90%). Patients with a posterior dislocation of the hip generally present with a shortened, internally rotated, adducted limb in slight flexion. If the hip is adducted at the time of injury, a pure dislocation occurs, whereas a neutral position or abduction leads to fracture dislocation. It is associated with a fracture of the femoral head or acetabulum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The limb appears lengthened and in FABER (flexion, abduction, external rotation) deformity in anterior dislocation of the hip following a motor vehicle accident.
  • Thus, in the given scenario, the patient has anterior dislocation of the hip.

choices.text: Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint.
Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential.
Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone.
Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy came with a tumor resembling a mushroom in the distal femur, which has been present for the last two years. What characteristics should the clinician look for to discern a potential malignant transformation? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hyaline cap thickness on MRI is 2cms.

 

  • The provided X-ray reveals a clearly defined exostosis, indicating a diagnosis of osteochondroma.
  • Additionally, the hyaline cap thickness of 2cms observed on the MRI raises concerns about the possibility of malignant transformation.

 

OSTEOCHONDROMA

 

  • Osteochondroma is the commonest benign “tumour” of the bone.
  • It is not a true neoplasm since its growth stops with cessation of growth at the epiphyseal plate.
  • It is the developmental malformation thought to originate within the periosteum as small cartilaginous nodules.
  • X-ray shows an osseous outgrowth arising from the medial aspect of the distal femur and directed upwards (away from the joint), its cortex appears continuous with that of the femur.
  • Osteochondroma shows a bone with cartilage cap that is irregular and usually cannot be seen on radiographs, a result of development malformation.
  • Occasionally, calcification within the cap may be seen which usually angle away from the growth plate.
  • Typically, the cap is only a few millimeters thick in adults, although it may be 2 cm thick in a child.
  • An osseus outgrowth grows away from bone and grows till skeletal maturity.
  • Osteochondromas are found on the metaphysis of a long bone near the physis.
  • They are seen most often on the distal femur, proximal tibia, and proximal humerus.
  • Many of these lesions cause no symptoms and are discovered incidentally.
  • Pain may be present due to bursitis or malignant transformation.
  • Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; has enlarged further after skeletal maturity, there is loss of corticomedullary differentiation.
  • It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma.
  • In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick. (Best evaluated by MRI).
  • Osteochondromas are of two types: Pedunculated and broad- based or sessile.
  • Pedunculated tumors are more common. The stalk is directed away from the physis adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the parent bone.
  • The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap
  • Treatment: 
    • Surgery (en bloc resection-extraperiosteal resection) is indicated for lesion that causes pain, symptomatic impingement on neurovascular structure, compromise of joint function, cosmetic deformity, painful bursa formation and rapid increase in size of lesion or when imaging features suggest malignancy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initially growth of the tumor was away from the joint, now the growth of tumor is towards the joint. This is not true for an osteochondroma. The lesion is covered by a cartilaginous cap which is irregular and usually grows away from the growth plate.

 

Option B. Tumor does not have malignant transformation potential. This is not true. The incidence of malignant degeneration is approximately 1% for patients with a solitary osteochondroma and 6% for patients with multiple hereditary exostoses. Malignant transformation should be suspected when a previously quiescent lesion in an adult grows rapidly; any further enlargement after skeletal maturity takes place, loss of corticomedullary differentiation takes place. It usually takes the form of a low-grade chondrosarcoma. In these cases, the cartilage cap usually is more than 2 cm thick which can be best evaluated by MRI).

 

Option C. Tumor is in continuation with bone marrow cavity of the normal bone. This is not true. The stalk of the lesion grows away from the physis, adjacent to which it takes its origin. The projecting part of the lesion has cortical and cancellous components, both of which are continuous with the corresponding components of the parent bone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The malignant transformation of osteochondroma is suspected when the hyaline cap thickness is 2cm, as seen on the MRI.

questions.text: Given below is an X-ray of shoulder of a 25-year-old male who suffered a shoulder injury and now exhibits swelling around the shoulder joint. Based on the X-ray, which structure(s) is/are probable sites of injury? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Both acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligament

 

  • The provided image indicates an upward displacement of the clavicle, accompanied by a noticeable gap between the clavicle and the acromion.
  • This suggests potential injuries to both the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

 

ACROMIOCLAVICULAR JOINT DISLOCATION

 

  • Acromioclavicular (AC) joint injury typically occurs due to a fall onto the acromion.
  • Stability of the AC joint is dependent upon both the AC and coracoclavicular (CC) ligaments.
  • An acromioclavicular joint separation occurs when the clavicle separates from the scapula.
  • It is commonly caused by a fall directly on the ‘point’ of the shoulder or by a direct blow received in a contact sport.
  • AC Joint separation is almost always the result of a sudden, traumatic event that can be attributed to a specific incident or action.
  • The two most common causes are either a direct blow to the shoulder (seen in football, rugby, or hockey), or a fall on to an outstretched hand (after falling off a bicycle).
  • Symptoms:
    • Pain and swelling around the joint
    • Pain on movement of the arm
    • Depending on the grade, a bump may be present on the top of the shoulder where the clavicle ends
    • The joint may be very unstable
  • It is classified into type 1 to 6 by Rockwood classification according to the severity of the injury and position of the displaced bones.

 

 

 

 

  • Treatment according to the grades include:
    • Type I-III: Conservative management with velpeau bandage. The bandage pushes the lateral end of shoulder downwards and the arm upwards, thus maintaining the reduction.
    • Type IV-VI: Open reduction and internal fixation

 

Other Option:

 

Option C. Coracoacromial ligament. Coracoacromial ligament originates from the medial border of the acromion and attaches to the lateral border of the coracoid process. This ligament forms a part of the coracoacromial arch and provides support to the humeral head. Coracoacromial ligament injury is mostly related to trauma or clavicular fracture and isolated injury to the coracoacromial ligament is rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acromioclavicular joint dislocation or separation, as shown in the image provided in the question, there is tear in the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments.

choices.text: Bipartite patella; X-ray of other knee

questions.text: Shown below is an X-ray of a patient with history of a chronic knee pain. True statement concerning the X-ray shown would be: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Bipartite patella; X-ray other knee

 

BIPARTITE PATELLA

 

  • It is the congenital fragmentation of patella.
  • In this condition, the patella is made up of two separate bones instead of one.
  • It occurs when the patella fails to fuse properly during development, leading to a bipartite appearance.
  • This condition is typically asymptomatic and may go unnoticed for many years.
  • In some cases, it can cause pain, swelling, or discomfort, especially during physical activity.
  • The X-ray of opposite knee must be taken as the condition is bilateral in 50% of cases and this condition is more common in males than females.

 

 

  • Management usually involves conservative measures to alleviate symptoms like rest, ice, and physical therapy to strengthen the Quadriceps muscles, and reduce stress on the patella.
  • In more severe cases, a brace may be recommended to provide additional support and reduce stress on the patella.
  • Pain medications and anti-inflammatory drugs may also be prescribed to relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • If conservative measures fail to provide relief, surgery may be considered. Surgery typically involves removing the smaller bone fragment and smoothing the joint surface to reduce friction and alleviate pain.
  • In rare cases, surgery may involve fusing the two patellar fragments together to create a single patella.
  • With appropriate treatment, most people can return to their normal activities without significant limitations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Avulsion fracture; cylindrical cast. In avulsion fracture of PCL alone, the non-operative treatment relies on restoration of tibiofemoral relationship with immobilization, followed by physiotherapy. In the first 6 weeks, immobilization and limited weight bearing is achieved using a cylindrical cast in 15° flexion or with posterior support in the form of extension or dynamic anterior drawer brace to prevent subluxation of tibia.
