Option C. Avulsion fracture; wire fixation. K-wire fixation is done for distal phalanx base avulsion fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image in the question shows bipartite patella which is a congenital fragmentation of patella i.e., the patella is made of two separate bones instead of one.
  • In this condition, it is always recommended to get an x-ray of the other knee also as this condition is bilateral in most cases.
  • It is treated by surgical removal of the smaller bone fragment when the conservative methods fail to provide relief.

choices.text: a, b, c, d are correct

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are correct regarding investigation of malignant bone tumors? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

 

  1. Always done by transverse incision.
  2. Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  3. Sample should be taken before any radiological investigations.
  4. Sample should be taken from periphery and not from necrotic centre.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b and d are correct

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor. 

 

SIMPLE BONE CYST

 

  • Simple bone cysts are a common pseudotumor of bone and the most frequent cause of pathologic fractures in children.
  • Bone cysts usually affect patients between 5 and 15 years of age and occur more often in boys than in girls (2:1).
  • They are found in the proximal humerus in 50% of cases and in the upper femur in 25%. The calcaneus and pelvis are also uniquely common locations.
  • Patients are asymptomatic until a pathologic fracture occurs.
  • Radiographs typically show a solitary cyst that is centrally located in the metaphyseal area and has marked thinning of the adjacent cortical bone and a pseudoloculated appearance.
  • If there is associated fracture, radiographs may show the characteristic “fallen leaf” sign.
  • In weight-bearing bones, such as the proximal femur, lesions should be treated aggressively.
  • Management:
    • Initial management usually involves aspiration/injection with either bone marrow or corticosteroid.
    • The injections are carried out with bone biopsy needles and are repeated three to five times at intervals of 2 to 3 months, depending on the radiographic response.
    • Curettage and bone grafting may also be an effective modality.

 

OSTEOID OSTEOMA

 

  • The most common benign osteoid-forming tumor is the osteoid osteoma, accounting for 10% of all benign bone tumors.
  • It is more common in males than in females with a peak incidence in the second decade of life.
  • Although it may be present in almost any bone, the proximal femur is the most common location.
  • Dull, aching, nocturnal pain is characteristic, and  it is commonly relieved entirely by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) secondary to a high concentration of prostaglandins in the nidus.
  • Radiographic Feature:
    • Central, lytic nidus usually 1 cm or less in diameter. The more common cortically-based lesion exhibits extensive reactive sclerosis, creating a fusiform bulge on the bone surface. If the nidus is close to, or actually in, a joint, as in a femoral neck lesion, the resulting reactive synovitis may mimic a pyarthrosis or rheumatoid arthritis.
    • Technetium bone scans are invariably positive.
    • A CT scan is recommended to better anatomically locate the nidus and confirm the diagnosis.
    • In the spine, the typical location for an osteoid osteoma is in the posterior elements.
  • Management:
    • Many cases of osteoid osteoma are stage 1 lesions and can be treated symptomatically with aspirin or NSAIDs until they spontaneously resolve.
    • If the patient fails such treatment, intervention is warranted.
    • CT-guided radiofrequency ablation has emerged as the preferred treatment modality in many cases.
    • If open surgical excision is undertaken, the entire nidus must be eradicated.

 

GIANT-CELL TUMOR (OSTEOCLASTOMA)

 

  • It is bone lesion of uncertain origin, most commonly seen in distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus and distal radius.
  • Most commonly seen in 20-40 years of age, after epiphyseal fusion.
  • Histology: 
    • Multinucleated giant cells are seen on a background of stromal cells with little or no visible intercellular tissue.
    • The osteoclast giant cells are the malignant cells, which induce the proliferation of mononuclear macrophage-lineage cells, hence the dividing cell population is the mononuclear cells which form the matrix.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Most commonly presents with pain, with or without swelling
    • Pathological fracture occurs in 10–15% of cases
    • Pulmonary metastasis occurs in 4% of cases, but they usually regress spontaneously.
  • Radiological features:
    • Eccentric lytic lesion at epiphyseal region, bounded by subchondral bone plate, with soap bubble appearance.
    • Biopsy is necessary for confirming the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Curettage and ‘stripping’ of the cavity, followed by swabbing with hydrogen peroxide or by the application of liquid nitrogen.
    • More aggressive tumors and recurrent lesions: Excision followed by bone grafting.

 

OSTEOSARCOMA

 

  • The classic form of osteosarcoma is typically seen in patients in their second or third decade, with a peak in the adolescent growth spurt.
  • Incidence is Males > Females and is found in the metaphyseal areas of long bones, with 50% of lesions about the knee joint.
  • The distal femur is the most common site, followed by the proximal tibia and then the proximal humerus.
  • Radiographic Findings:
    • Permeated lytic destruction of metaphyseal bone, with eventual cortical breakthrough into the subperiosteal space and subsequent formation of a Codman triangle at the diaphyseal end of the tumor.
    • As the tumor continues to push its way into the extracortical soft tissue, a typical sunburst pattern of neoplastic bone may be seen outside the involved bone.
  • Management:
    • With the combination of chemotherapy and surgical treatment, the prognosis for 5-year survival is 70-80%.
    • The drugs commonly used today include high-dose methotrexate, doxorubicin, cisplatin, and ifosfamide.
    • In osteosarcoma of the extremities, limb-sparing surgery with wide resection of the tumor is the standard approach.
    • Amputation is reserved for the exceptional or recurrent case.

 

Educational Objective :

 

  • Longitudinal incision is given for bone biopsy.
  • Sample should be taken from 2 different planes.
  • Radiological investigations are usually done before the biopsy.
  • It is better to take tissue at the periphery of the lesion, where there are viable cells. On the contrary, necrosis and so nondiagnostic tissue are usually present within the tumor.

questions.text: Which method of measurement of scoliosis has been depicted in the image given below? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cobb’s angle

 

  • This X-ray of spine shows lateral curvature (scoliosis) and angle marked is for its measurement – Cobb’s angle.

 

COBB’S ANGLE

 

  • Most widely used measurement to quantify the magnitude of spinal scoliosis, on plain radiographs.
  • Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of >10°.
  • A Cobb angle can also aid kyphosis or lordosis assessment in the sagittal plane.
  • Measurement:
    • To measure the Cobb angle, one must first decide which vertebrae are the end vertebrae of the curve deformity (the terminal vertebrae) – the vertebra whose endplates are most tilted towards each other. 
    • Lines are then drawn along the endplates (or the pedicles if the endplates are not properly visualized), and the angle between the two lines, where they intersect, measured. 
    • In cases where the curvature is not marked, then the lines will not intersect on the film/monitor, in which case a further two lines can be plotted, each at right angles to the previous lines.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kite’s angle. Kite’s angle or talocalcaneal angle is the angle between the lines drawn down the axis of the talus and calcaneus measured on weight bearing foot radiograph. This angle varies depending on the position of the calcaneus under the talus and the stiffness of the foot ligaments. Measurement: midtalar line should pass through/just medial to the base of 1st metatarsal and the mid-calcaneal line should pass through the base of 4th metatarsal. In hindfoot varus, the talocalcaneal angle is < 25⁰; in hindfoot valgus, it is > 40⁰; while in a normal foot, it is 25-40⁰.

 

 

Option C. Bohler’s angle. Tuber angle of Bohler (Tuber-joint angle) is used in the assessment of intra-articular calcaneal fractures. It is formed between a line drawn from highest points of anterior process of the calcaneus and highest point of posterior facet, and a line drawn tangentially to the superior edge of the calcaneal tuberosity. It is normally 20-40 degrees. Flattening/Reduction/Reversal of this angle indicates that the weight-bearing posterior facet has collapsed (intra-articular fracture) or Degree of proximal displacement of the tuberosity (intra-articular and extra-articular fracture both).

 

 

Option D. Gissane angle. Also known as critical angle of Gissane, it is used to evaluate the severity of calcaneal fractures. It is formed by two cortical struts extending laterally, one along the lateral margin of posterior facet and other extending to the beak of the calcaneus. Normally, it is an obtuse angle of 95-105 degree. It increases in intra-articular fractures.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows the Cobb’s angle, which is used for the measurement of degree of lateral curvature of the spine in scoliosis.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: A 15-year-old male presents with the following x-ray of knee. It is suggestive of: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

 

  • The given image shows the Codman’s triangle which is a characteristic radiological finding in osteosarcoma. 
  • Codman's triangle is a periosteal reaction, seen on X-ray, characterized by the lifting of the periosteum with a triangular piece of dense calcification underneath. 
  • This appearance is indicative of an aggressive periosteal reaction. 
  • It is commonly associated with malignant lesions or chronic processes, with osteosarcoma being a typical example.
  • Sun Ray Appearance is another X-ray finding where there are multiple radiating spicules extending from a bone, resembling rays of the sun. 

 

Note - While these periosteal reactions are highly suggestive of certain bone conditions, they are not diagnostic on their own. The definitive diagnosis of bone lesions, whether benign or malignant, is confirmed through a tissue biopsy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ewing’s Sarcoma: Ewing's sarcoma can show aggressive periosteal reactions such as an onion peel appearance.

 

 

Option C. Osteochondroma: This is a benign bone growth that typically have a distinct appearance with an exostosis pointing away from the joint.

 

 

Option D. Osteomyelitis: This condition can show a periosteal reaction, but it is usually a solid, narrow zone reaction and not the wide zone reaction like Codman's triangle.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Codman's triangle on an X-ray is a suggestive sign of osteosarcoma, a malignant bone tumor.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to your clinic with the following deformity of the right arm. Which is the most likely fracture leading to such a defect? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Supracondylar fracture

 

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURE OF THE HUMERUS

 

  • This is one of the most serious fractures in childhood as it is often associated with complications. 
  • Most common elbow fractures – 50-70%
  • Mechanism:
    • The fracture is caused by a fall on an out-stretched hand. 
    • As the hand strikes the ground, the elbow is forced into hyperextension resulting in fracture of the humerus above the condyles. 
  • Pathoanatomy:
    • The fracture line extends transversely through the distal metaphysis of humerus just above the condyles. 
  • Types:
    • A supracondylar fracture may be of extension or flexion type, depending upon the displacement of the distal fragment. 
    • The extension type is the commoner (98%) of the two. 
    • In this, the distal fragment is extended (tilted backwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
    • In the flexion type, the distal fragment is flexed (tilted forwards) in relation to the proximal fragment. 
  • Treatment:
    • Closed reduction and cast
    • If conservative management fails or if fracture is displaced, closed reduction and K-wire fixation is done.
  • Complications:
    • Malunion – most common 
    • Posteromedial displacement develops cubitus varus/gunstock deformity
    • Nerve injury: Anterior interosseous nerve most commonly injured followed by median, radial and ulnar nerves – transient neuropraxia occurs 
    • Vessel injury: Brachial artery 
    • Volkmann’s ischemia and compartment syndrome 
    • Elbow stiffness 
    • Myositis ossificans 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Colle’s fracture. Colles fracture is fracture of lower end of radius at its corti-cocancellous junction mostly occurring in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women; as a result of fall on outstretched hand, with wrist in extension. It is one of the most common fractures in elderly. It is commonly associated with dinner fork deformity. It is treated successfully with a hand-shaking cast. Finger stiffness is the most common complication. Malunion is the 2nd most common complication, leading to dinner fork deformity. Colle’s fracture is the commonest cause of sudeck’s dystrophy in the upper limb. 

 

 

Option B. Lateral epicondyle fracture. Lateral humeral condyle fractures are the second most commonly encountered elbow fractures after supracondylar fractures in the pediatric age group. These fractures are intra-articular and are prone to displacement owing to the attachment of the forearm extensor muscles on the lateral condyle. Due to this, they can produce various complications, including elbow deformity, if not appropriately managed. Displaced fractures are at a higher risk of non-union. Malunion, cubitus varus, avascular necrosis, and post-operative infection are recognized complications following surgery. The most common mechanism is a fall on the outstretched hand with the elbow in extension and the forearm in supination. Fractures with <2mm displacement can have conservative treatment. The indications of surgery are fracture displacement >2 mm and articular surface incongruency. Closed reduction and percutaneous fixation are options.

 

 

Option C. Medial epicondyle fracture. A medial epicondyle fracture is an avulsion injury of the attachment of the common flexors of the forearm. The injury is usually extra-articular but can be sometimes associated with an elbow dislocation. Medial epicondyle fractures are common and account for 10% of all elbow fractures in children. They occur between the ages of 7-15 years. They are usually a result from an avulsion injury caused by a valgus stress at the elbow and contraction of the flexor muscles. Potential complications include medial elbow instability and nonunion.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The given image shows a gunstock deformity i.e., cubitus varus deformity of the elbow after malunion of the supracondylar fracture of the humerus.

questions.text: Which clinical test will be positive in a patient who comes with a neglected traumatic dislocation of the hip? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Telescopy test

 

TELESCOPY TEST

 

  • Telescopy Test is a provocative test used to evaluate the stability of the hip joint.
  • It also indicates the congenital hip dislocation in pediatric patients.
  • Steps to perform the test:
    • The patient is positioned supine on the examination table, and the examiner stands on the side that is to be examined.
    • The hip and knee are flexed to 90° and the hip is kept in mild adduction.
    • The pelvis is supported with one hand by placing the thenar eminence over the ASIS and the fingers on the greater trochanter to feel the instability.
    • The knee/ distal thigh is held with the other hand, and a gentle push and pull force is applied along the long axis of the thigh.
       
  • If the hip is unstable, an up and down trochanteric excursion can be felt with the other hand, the test is said to be positive.
  • When the excursion is more than that compared to the other side, think of conditions like a femoral neck fracture nonunion, hip dislocation, old unreduced posterior hip dislocation, dislocated total hip replacement.
  • Causes of positive telescopy test:
    1. Girdlestone arthroplasty
    2. Old unreduced dislocation with lax structures
    3. Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip
    4. Pathological dislocation e.g. TB
    5. Charcot’s joint
    6. Perthes disease
    7. Slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE)
    8. Squeal of septic arthritis
    9. Osteonecrosis with collapse
    10. TB hip: Mortar and pestle type, destroyed head, wandering acetabulum
    11. Non Union fracture neck femur
    12. Non Union fracture intertrochanteric

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thomas test. It is done to measure fixed flexion deformity of hip by neutralizing lumbar lordosis. Up to 30 degree flexion deformity of hip can be compensated by lumbar lordosis. It measures hip flexor length and distinguishes tightness between one joint and two joint muscles.

 

 

Option C. McMurray test. McMurray's test is used to determine the presence of a meniscal tear within the knee. If there is meniscal injury, the test will be positive. A positive McMurray test will have findings of pain, snapping, an audible clicking, and locking in the knee on performing the test. Any of these symptoms can indicate a compromised medial or lateral meniscus.

 

 

Option D. Lasegue test. The Straight Leg Raise (SLR) test is commonly used to identify disc pathology or nerve root irritation, as it mechanically stresses lumbosacral nerve roots. It also has specific importance in detecting disc herniation and neural compression. It is also classified as a neurodynamic evaluation test as it can detect excessive nerve root tension or compression. Inclusion of ankle dorsiflexion in the SLR is documented as Lasegue's test. A true positive SLR test should include:

 

  • Radicular leg pain (symptoms below the knee).
  • Pain on hip flexion at 30 and 60 or 70 degrees from horizontal.
  • Neurological pain reproduced in the leg and lower back between 30-70 degrees of hip flexion is suggestive of lumbar disc herniation at the L4-S1 nerve roots.
  • Pain at greater than 70 degrees of hip flexion might indicate tightness of the hamstrings, gluteus maximus, or hip capsule, or pathology of the hip or sacroiliac joints.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Telescopy test is positive in cases of old, neglected, and traumatic hip dislocations.

questions.text: Identify the brace given in the following image:(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Milwaukee brace

 

  • The brace given in the image is Milwaukee brace that is used for scoliosis.

 

SCOLIOSIS

 

  • Scoliosis is characterized by lateral curvature of the spine associated with rotation of the involved vertebrae and classified by its anatomic location, in either the thoracic or lumbar spine, with rare involvement of the cervical spine.
  • There are four main categories of scoliosis: 
    1. Idiopathic: Idiopathic scoliosis accounts for around 80% of cases. It is more common in girls and typically develops around 10-12 years of age, but can occur earlier. There is a genetic component, but the etiology is multifactorial.
    2. Congenital: Congenital scoliosis accounts for 5-7% of cases and is a result of vertebral abnormalities due to a failure of formation or segmentation of the affected vertebrae.
    3. Neuromuscular (associated with a neurological or muscular disease)
    4. Syndromic (associated with a known syndrome)
       
  • Types of scoliosis:

 

 

  • Clinical Findings:
    • Scoliosis in adolescents does not typically cause significant pain. If a patient has significant pain, she/he should be evaluated to rule out the possibility of some other disorder such as infection or tumor.
    • Deformity of the rib cage and asymmetry of the waistline are clinically evident for curvatures of 30 degrees or more.
    • Lesser curves may be detected through a forward bending test (Adam’s test), which is designed to detect early abnormalities of rotation that may not be apparent when the patient is standing erect.
    • Rotation of the spine may be measured with a scoliometer. Rotation is associated with a marked rib hump as the lateral curvature increases in severity.
       
  • Imaging:
    • Radiographs taken of the entire spine in the standing position in both the posterior anterior (PA) and lateral planes are the most valuable for diagnosis.
    • Usually, a primary curve is evident with compensatory curvature to balance the body.
    • Skeletal maturity can be assessed by the Risser sign. A radiograph is employed to see how far the patient's iliac apophysis has progressed from the anterior superior iliac spine. During development, the iliac apophysis first appears laterally and grows medially. The stages are Risser I-V, where Risser V denotes that the apophysis has completely fused with the iliac crest and therefore, skeletal maturity can be assumed hence, further progression of curve of scoliosis will not take place.

 

 

  • Treatment:
    • Treatment of scoliosis depends on the curve magnitude, skeletal maturity, and risk of progression.
    • Specific management is dependent on the Cobb angle, measured on a standing PA X-ray of the spine.
    • Brace treatment is restricted to immature children in an attempt to prevent curve progression during further skeletal growth. So, it is indicated in Growing adolescents (Risser 0, 1 or 2) who, on presentation, have curves in range of 30-45 degrees or who have had documented progression exceeding 5 degrees in curve that initially measured 20-30 degrees.
    • TLSOs are the most commonly used orthoses today, but their use is restricted to patients whose curve apex is at or below T7.
    • Suspensory plaster cast of sayre, Rissers cast hinge or turnbuckle cast of Hibbs and Kisser, Milwaukee brace, Boston brace, Charleston night-time bending brace, Wilmington brace and thoraco-lumbo- sacral orthoses (TLSOs) are used to treat idiopathic scoliosis (Lower Dorsal scoliosis > Lumbar Scoliosis).
    • Surgical treatment consists of corrective osteotomies and fusion.
    • Spinal instrumentation (rods,  screws, hooks, etc.) are applied to the region of the spine to be corrected through transpedicular route and bone graft is added.
    • Spinal fusions are delayed as long as possible in young children through the use of casting, bracing, and growth modulating surgeries such as growing rods or vertical expandable prosthetic titanium ribs (VEPTR).

 

 

  • Milwaukee Brace: 
    • The Milwaukee brace is an active corrective spinal orthosis.
    • It consists of a neck ring with a throat mould and two occipital pads to avoid a high pressure in the neck.
    • Other elements are a plastic pelvic girdle, aluminium uprights, leather L-shaped thoracic pads and metal bars in the front and in the back.
    • It is used in the treatment of postural disorders like idiopathic scoliosis or Scheuerman disease.
    • The brace is normally prescribed for children, with a postural disorder, who have not reached their growth spurt or who are in their fast growing period.
    • It is not used for adults or adolescents already beyond their growth spurt, as it will have no effect.
    • If the spinal curve has a Cobb angle between 20° and 40°, it is an indication to use a brace.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The brace shown in the image in the question is of a Milwaukee brace, which is used to treat scoliosis in adolescent children.

choices.text: Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius
Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

questions.text: An old lady fell in the bathroom with an outstretched hand. She was managed conservatively. Later on, she developed the deformity as shown in the figure. Most likely fracture sustained was:(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extra-articular fracture distal end of radius

 

COLLE’S FRACTURE

 

  • Fracture of the distal end of radius at its corticocancellous junction, is commonly referred to as a Colle’s fracture.
  • It is typically the result of a FOOSH injury (Fall on outstretched hand) with wrist in extension.
  • It mostly occur in post-menopausal osteoporotic elderly women.
  • Symptoms and Signs:
    • Patients present with swelling, ecchymosis, tenderness, and painful range of motion of the distal forearm.
    • On examination, the classic “dinner fork” deformity (dorsal displacement of the distal fragment and volar angulation of the distal intact radius with radial shortening) may be identified.

 

 

 

  • Complications:
    • Early complications may include median nerve neuropathy, extensor pollicis longus tendon rupture, and compartment syndrome.
    • Late complications may include radiocarpal arthrosis, complex regional pain syndrome, cosmetic changes of the wrist, and fracture malunion or nonunion.
    • Finger stiffness is most common complication.
    • Malunion is the 2nd most common complication and it leads to dinner fork deformity.
    • Colles fracture is the commonest cause of Sudeck's dystrophy in upper limb.
       
  • Treatment:
    • Non-displaced extra-articular fractures are relatively stable and are treated non-operatively with a long-arm splint acutely to allow for swelling, then transitioned to a short-arm cast.
    • The cast is applied on opposite forces to displacement. The position of immobilization is:

 

  • Displaced fractures should undergo an attempt at closed reduction followed by immobilization in a long-arm sugar-tong splint acutely. Surgical fixation is indicated for distal radius fractures that fail to meet acceptable alignment criteria. Various methods include closed reduction percutaneous pinning, external fixation, and open reduction internal fixation (ORIF).
     
  • Technique of closed manipulation:
    • The muscles of forearm must be relaxed, either by general or regional anaesthesia. The surgeon grasps the injured hand as if he was ‘shaking hands’.

 

  • The first step is to disimpact the fragments which have often been driven together.

  • This is achieved by firm longitudinal traction to the hand against the counter-traction by an assistant who grasps the arm above the flexed elbow.

  • The surgeon now presses the distal fragment into palmar flexion and ulnar deviation using the thumb of his other hand.

  • As this is done, the patient’s hand is drawn into pronation, palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

A plaster cast is applied extending from below the elbow to the metacarpal heads, maintaining the wrist in palmar flexion and ulnar deviation.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Intra-articular fracture distal end of radius. Barton's fracture is the displaced intra-articular coronal plane fracture-subluxation of dorsal lip of the distal radius with displacement of carpus with the fragment. Intra-articular component usually signifies high-energy trauma occurring in young adults, causing shear and impacted fractures of the articular surface of the distal aspect of the radius with displacement of the fracture fragments. The fracture pattern most commonly observed in geriatric age group is extra-articular while the high-energy intra-articular type is most frequent in young adult patients. Melone's classification of intra-articular distal radius fractures:

 

 

 

Intra-articular fractures of distal end of the radius can be difficult to treat, at times, with traditional conservative method. Type I and type II Melone's fracture can be managed conservatively by closed reduction and cast immobilization. External fixation is accepted as superior to plaster immobilization in the young patients with an intra-articular comminuted fracture of the distal radius. Complex intra-articular fractures in which the articular fragments are displaced, rotated or impacted are treated with open reduction and internal fixation.

 

Option C. Scaphoid fracture. It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. Fullness and tenderness is felt in anatomical snuff box. In adults and adolescents, middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) is more common. Nondisplaced, Stable Fractures are treated conservatively by Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast. Displaced, Unstable Fractures are treated by Headless Screw (Herbert).

 

 

 

Scaphoid glass holding cast

 

Option D. Dislocation of wrist. Wrist dislocations can occur at the radiocarpal joint, the midcarpal joint, the distal radioulnar joint or may represent a combination of these injuries in severe trauma. Carpal instability in the form of lunate and perilunate dislocations are uncommon injuries but can be frequently missed. The majority of carpal instability is centered around the lunate, given its location in the middle of the wrist. Injuries progress from scapholunate instability to lunate dislocation. Perilunate dislocations and lunate dislocations are high-energy wrist injuries involving falls from height, motor vehicle collisions, or athletic injuries. Lunate dislocate anteriorly but the rest of the carpals remain in position. In Perilunate dislocation, the lunate remains in position and the rest of the carpals dislocate dorsally. The most common type of perilunate instability is transscaphoid perilunate fracture dislocation. Median nerve is most commonly involved nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is Tavernier’s maneuver.

 

 

A) Normal; (B) Lunate dislocation; (C) Perilunate dislocation; (D) Normal

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The image shown in the question is a classic dinner fork deformity, which is a complication of Colle’s fracture.
  • Colle’s fracture is most commonly seen in post-menopausal osteoporotic females after a fall on outstretched hand.

choices.text: Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is independently a true/correct statement but the Reason is independently an incorrect/false statement
Assertion is independently a false/incorrect statement but the reason is independently a true/correct statement

questions.text:
Assertion: Decompression surgery is needed with progressive neurological difficulty in Pott’s spine. (AIIMS May 2019)

 

Reason: Even after completion of ATT, there can be neurological abnormalities.
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Both assertion and reasoning are independently true/correct and reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • The spine is the most common site of skeletal tuberculosis, accounting for 50% of cases followed by hip (15%) and knee (10%).
  • Any level of the spine may be involved, the lower thoracic region being the most common followed by lumbar > upper dorsal > cervical > sacral region.
  • Types:

 

 

  • Clinical features: Pain, stiffness, cold abscess formation, paraplegia, deformity, fever, weight loss.
  • Imaging:
    1. Plain radiograph:
      • Reduction of disc space
      • Vertebral body destruction
      • Paravertebral abscess
      • Widening of mediastinum
    2. CT scan: 
      • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
    3. MRI: 
      • It is the investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
      • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.
    4. Biopsy: 
      • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.
  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: Patient has no neural complaint clinician elicits increased reflexes.
    • Stage 2: Patient has weakness but can walk with support.
    • Stage 3: Patient is non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%.
    • Stage 4: Patient has bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%.
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India.
    • Patient is treated by antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on nonoperative management but if indications of surgery exist  then he needs to be operated.
  • Stage-wise Treatment:

 

 

  • ATT: 
    • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
    • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB, the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
  • Indications of surgery in any disease of spine:
    1. Bowel bladder involvement.
    2. Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
    3. No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks or
    4. Surgical options for most of the cases are: anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
    5. Hong Kong operation is also carried out for Pott’s spine.
    6. Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed).

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

Note:

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.

 

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When there is stage 4 of pott’s spine with bladder/bowel involvement and more than 50% of sensory loss, the treatment of choice is decompression surgery with bone graft, along with continuation of ATT.
  • Even after the completion of ATT, there can be presence of neurological abnormalities.

questions.text: Most common pattern of involvement of Pott’s spine is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Paradiscal

 

POTT’S SPINE

 

  • Like tuberculosis of the bones and joints elsewhere in the body, TB of the spine is always secondary.
  • The tubercular spread to spine usually takes place from Lungs > lymph nodes.
  • The bacteria reach the spine via the hematogenous route, from the lungs or lymph nodes.
  • Types of vertebral tuberculosis:

 

A. Paradiscal: This is the commonest type. In this, the contiguous areas of two adjacent vertebrae along with the intervening disc are affected.

 

 

B. Central: In this type, the body of a single vertebra is affected. This leads to early collapse of the weakened vertebra. The nearby disc may be normal. The collapse may be a ‘wedging’ or ‘concertina’ collapse; wedging being more common.

 

C. Anterior: In this type, infection is localised to the anterior part of the vertebral body. The infection spreads up and down under the anterior longitudinal ligament.

 

D. Posterior: This is the least common type. In this type, the posterior complex of the vertebra, i.e., the pedicle, lamina, spinous process and transverse process are affected.

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common > central type > anterior type > appendiceal type (involving pedicle, lamina, and less commonly transverse process, 2nd least common is spinous process and rarest variety is synovitis of facet joints).
  • Clinical features: 
    • Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest and 1st symptom.
    • Tenderness is the earliest sign.
    • Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension – Coin test
    • Earliest sign of  neurological deficit – increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response.
    • The prominence of 2-3 spinous process, called angular kyphosis is commonest in tuberculosis because of 2 contiguous vertebra involved with paradiscal destruction.
    • In the thoracic region, kyphosis is most marked because of normal kyphotic curvature.

 

 

  • Tuberculosis is the most common cause of cold abscess.
  • Psoas abscess can give rise to pseudo-hip flexion deformity
  • Paraplegia occurs most often in upper thoracic region.∙
  • Early onset paresis is due to inflammatory edema, granulation tissue, an abscess, caseous material. It has good prognosis.
  • Late onset paresis is due to increasing deformity or reactivation of disease, bony sequestrum, stenosis of the vertebral canal, fibrosis or vascular insufficiency and has poor prognosis.
  • Sequelae of TB spine is usually bony ankylosis.

 

  • Imaging:
  • Plain radiograph: 
    • Earliest X-ray feature is loss of Curvature due to paravertebral spasm.
    • Reduction of disc space
    • Vertebral body destruction
    • Paravertebral abscess appears as fusiform shadows along vertebral column.
    • Widening of mediastinum
       
  • CT scan: 
    • It may detect a small paravertebral abscess, not otherwise seen on plain X-ray; may indicate precisely the extent of destruction of the vertebral body and posterior elements; and may show a sequestrum or a bony ridge pressing on the cord.
       
  • MRI:
    • Investigation of choice to evaluate the type and extent of compression of the cord.
    • It also shows condition of the underlying neural tissues, and thus helps in predicting the prognosis in a particular case.

 

 

  • Biopsy:
    • CT guided needle biopsy, or an open biopsy may be required in a case with doubtful diagnosis.

 

  • Stages of TB Spine with Neural Deficit:
    • Stage 1: no neural complaint; increased reflexes
    • Stage 2: weakness but can walk with support
    • Stage 3: non-ambulatory or has sensory loss <50%
    • Stage 4: bowel/bladder involvement or sensory loss >50%
       
       
  • Treatment:
    • Middle path regimen is used in India
    • Treatment is done with antitubercular therapy (ATT), spinal brace and rest.
    • Patient is followed on with complete neural examination and if progress is good then continued on non-operative management but if indications of surgery exists  then, surgery needs to be done.
    • Stage-wise Treatment:
      • Stage 1: ATT + rest + monthly neural examination
      • Stage 2: ATT + rest + weekly neural examination
      • Stage 3: ATT + rest + daily neural examination
      • Stage 4: ATT + Decompression and bone grafting
         
    • ATT: 
      • Rifampicin is always a part of all regimens.
      • Minimum duration is 9-12 months in spinal TB and may be given up to 18-24 months depending upon clinical, radiological (MRI) and hematological (ESR) healing (in non-spinal TB the duration of ATT is 6 months-1 year).
         
    • Indications of surgery: 
      • Bowel bladder involvement
      • Deterioration in neural or clinical status on treatment
      • No improvement in neural or clinical status after conservative trial of 3-4 weeks
         
  • Surgical options for most of the cases aren anterior decompression + bone grafting or anterolateral decompression + bone grafting and both have similar success rates.
  • Hong Kong operation is also carried out.
  • Structures removed in anterolateral decompression are part of rib, one side transverse process, one pedicle and small part of vertebral body (intercostal nerves are exposed)

 

 

Structures removed in anterolateral decompression

 

  • Posterior structures like lamina are never removed in tuberculosis because disease destroys anteriorly and if surgeon destroys posteriorly then there will be instability.
  • These surgeries are carried out in right lateral position (right side down and left side up) approaching the spine from left side as the vessel handled is aorta on left side which is thick muscular vessel with more resilience to handling pressure as compared to vena cava on right side which is friable to handle.
     

Prognostic Factors:

 

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The paradiscal type is most common pattern of involvement followed by central type followed by anterior type followed by the posterior type.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.
